igdb.name: Campfire Cooking
igdb.summary: Campfire Cooking is a puzzle game about relaxing moments in nature, as you prepare meals over a warm fire. Follow a family's vacation to beautiful and exotic hiking trails. Listen to stories, toast marshmallows, simmer fondue or play with magnets until each meal is ready to eat.

reviews.review:
One of the best puzzle games you can get. The game looks gorgeous, and the sound mimics the camping experience. The controls are easy to learn, The puzzles have a nice complexity to them, ranging from easy to tricky, but once you figure out a puzzle you've been stuck on, it's incredibly satisfying. 

+ Having the option to play levels in any order you want is also nice.
+ Wonderful Graphics and atmosphere as well as simple concept.
+ Smart innovative ideas, and rich with +100 Levels.

appDetails.name: Campfire Cooking
appDetails.detailed_description:
Campfire Cooking is a puzzle game about relaxing moments in nature, as you prepare meals over a warm fire. Discover the joy of cooking on a stick and test your problem-solving skills with some challenging campfire puzzles! The latest creation from Layton Hawkes is guaranteed to make you feel clever, hungry and eager to book your next woodland escape.


Solve tricky puzzles with one simple goal; prepare the all the food, cooked to perfection and with a hint of smoke. When each meal is ready it's time to trek to the next campsite. But don't be fooled: these puzzles are no walk in the park, and some of them are a hike up the mountain!



A year long trip and a lot of marshmallows to toast. Follow a vacation like no other and listen to the campers as they tell stories, laugh at each other’s jokes or moan about the lack of cell phone reception. Enjoy the simple moments they share around the fire while waiting for their food to be cooked.



Twist, rotate and jostle skewers around the fire until each meal is ready to eat. Push fondue pots, play with magnets or maybe just use a camping stove if the fire won't light. Discover clever ways to solve puzzles at each new locale.



Once you've visited all the campsites on one trail, why not hike to another? Each trail brings you new vistas brimming with color, different foods to cook and fresh fireside stories to hear. Take a journey from the deep woodlands to snow-capped peaks, and everywhere in between.

igdb.name: Spacecom
igdb.summary: A strategic-to-the-bone, star fleet command game in which deception, smart movement, and choices to battle decide victory or defeat.

reviews.review:
To make long story short:
It's a great game-simple, strategic, immersive (best ingredients for tasty cakegame base)
 
But it lacks players-the multiplayer is empty
So the cake is raw, you can only lick the spoon-won't last long

shame indeed

appDetails.name: SPACECOM
appDetails.detailed_description:
Game Demo

Not sure if you'll like the game? Download our DEMO and try our Single Player campaign and our challenging Multiplayer mode!
Get the Steam DEMO now!


About the Game

SPACECOM – a strategic-to-the-bone, starfleet command game in which deception, smart movement, and choices to battle decide victory or defeat.

No coincidence, no luck. Spacecom pushes your ability to strategize with a focus on real-time tactics and planning. Use proven maneuvers learned from military legends or devise your own plans.

Test your wits in single player campaign, go head-to-head with up to 5 opponents in multiplayer or experiment with new strategies in AI skirmish mode. Most of all, you'll need a bright mind, cunning, and sound tactics.

When the war begins, leave the little things behind and dive into austere soundscapes as you immerse yourself in starfleet command. From now on, what matters is your grasp of tactics and strategy, not how fast you can click. Spacecom is about creativity in planning, not complexity of game mechanics.

Key Features


  • Single player campaign that will test your wit in diverse tactical puzzles
  • Tense multiplayer - dominate up to 5 players per map
  • No coincidence, no luck. What matters is good planning and successful execution
  • Sound designed specifically to trigger strategic thinking
  • Minimalistic visual design inspired by military technology
  • Created to exalt smart thinking over fast clicking

Previews


"In a market currently dominated by MOBAs, SPACECOM is set to offer a more nich perspective on strategy. Focused on concise combat roles and managing supply routes, it's all about using limited resources, to outwit your friends." - GameTrailers.com

"What really strikes me is that all of this is presented in an incredibly minimalistic style.(...) There is none of the distraction of flashy visual effects or incredibly renderedenvironments, this is pure strategy.(...) For me, an advocate of game mechanics above all else, this is as close to pure space strategy as I’ve seen and I’m really looking forward to the finished product." - gaminglives.com

"Spacecom is an interesting idea, as a quick-play strategy game. In a genre that tends to frighten off newcomers, Spacecom is poised to be the title that welcomes them in with open arms, avoiding complexity while still offering that classic 4X feeling. " - Criticallysane.com

appDetails.supported_languages: English, French, German, Spanish, Polish, Russian
appDetails.reviews:
“With Spacecom 11bit studios created perfectly working game mechanics which prove that you do not need elaborate animations to produce an immersive effect. I found Spacecom even more exciting and involving than most triple-A games recently. I would highly recommend it to all people who like good games.”
9/10 – IGN Deutschland

“Spacecom is simple, both graphically and mechanically—so simple it could almost be a board game. And yet despite—or rather, because of—this unassuming exterior, there's a lot of depth for you to explore within a limited space. That's the kind of strategy I like! It's like playing an actual game of chess where each piece has a very defined set of rules versus a weird game of pseudo-chess where each pawn functions slightly differently and you won't really understand the point of half of them until you're fifty hours in. We like to say "Graphics don't matter! Graphics don't matter!" Well, here's your proof. Just bring your imagination to the table, and there's a deeply satisfying strategy game waiting for you.”
4/5 – PC World

“Spacecom is exactly what I like. Challenging, smart, addictive, stimulating and yet not overloaded with unnecessary things. Flow Combine & 11 bit studios production represents the real meaning of strategy games and it’s essence. Every single fan of this genre, not only those with space theme, should check Spacecom.”
8,5/10 – http://gry.onet.pl/recenzje/spacecom-recenzja-male-jest-piekne-a-jakie-madre/pw3gd

igdb.name: Planetoid Pioneers
igdb.summary: Bring your game ideas and feedback to life with the Planetoid Pioneers Contributor Edition! With its powerful engine and integrated tools, join us in evolving the concept of Early Access. Don’t just tell us what you would like to see in this 2D physics-based action exploration game - SHOW us!

reviews.review: A really fun game. It has interesting physics and its an origanal idea which is hard to come by these days in gaming. I like how you can drag PNG files into the game and it creates stuff. Only downsides is the physics need some work so people do not get stuck as often and maybe more saving progress with blueprints sicne it is tedious to get them every time I am on a new plantoid. Online multiplayer would make this game ALOT more funbecaucethere could be online pvp, story coop, sandbox, etc.

Just raw fun. Running away from a turrent and dolphin diving down a crack will never get old.

Also the full release is this thursday apparently... so that's awesome!

Planetoid Pioneers is a paid demo. (or not... check the bottom of the review for an edit I added)

I bought this game because it reminded me of Cortex Command, which I played a long time ago. This game gave me the nostalgia of playing it again, but Cortex Command gives you everything at full price, this game is just as fun, until you finish the levels. In cortex command it would make sense to jump into the editor, make your own content for the game, create your own fun. Planetoid Pioneers instead stops you dead in your tracks and says you have to pay 3x as much to get those priviledges, and the game is mainly supported by the fanbase, which has only just started and will probably die just as soon. So if you want a full game that is cheaper, more customizable, and just as fun to play, if you're okay with lower graphics, just get Cortex Command.

EDIT: If you've read this far, this was the first version of my review, the game is still in development and is gonna change after early access. Both versions of the game are gonna merge, I didn't know that, so now you can know too, it's a demo because it's not done, but it will be soon. So if you want something as good, or even better than cortex command, just wait a small bit and you'll get it.
reviews.developer_response:
Hi, and thanks for the passionate review!
Note that the version that is (very) soon going to be released out of early access (and what anyone who bought the Game-Only Edition will get without extra cost) will have the FULL editors included, so your argument that it's a "paid demo" is fortunately not very accurate.
We hope you might consider changing your review, now knowing this additional information :]

appDetails.name: Planetoid Pioneers
appDetails.detailed_description:
Welcome to Planetoid Pioneers, a physics-driven action-adventure heavily inspired by classics such as Blaster Master (‘88), Metroid (‘86), and Exile (‘88). It can be played locally with or against your friends in seamless pick-up-and-play Co-Op and PvP action.


If you buy the Game-Only Edition, you will today be able to explore over half a dozen planetoids, each featuring entirely different game modes and filled with vehicles, creatures, robots, items, and weapons created by us at Data Realms. You will also be able to choose from and subscribe to a rich set of user-generated content made by owners of the special Contributor Edition, which will keep expanding the Planetoid Pioneers experience in scope and depth for years to come. When Planetoid Pioneers exits Early Access, this regular edition will also get you all the editors unlocked at no extra cost - but not until then.



However, if you choose to purchase the Contributor Edition today, you will:
  • Get everything included in the Game-Only Edition, PLUS all the commercial-grade game development tools and live-editing capabilities of the Crush2D engine!
  • Become part of the well-established Contributor Community, where you can collaborate and directly share content with the development team and your fellow contributors.
  • Be able to submit your creations for consideration to be integrated into the official shipping game, with your name then appearing in the credits.
  • With a single button press, have the ability to publish whatever you make to the free Steam Workshop, for anyone to rate, comment, and subscribe to.

igdb.name: Limbo
igdb.summary: Limbo is a black and white puzzle-platforming adventure. Play the role of a young boy traveling through an eerie and treacherous world in an attempt to discover the fate of his sister. Limbo's design is an example of gaming as an art form. Short and sweet, doesn't overstay its welcome. Puzzles are challenging and fun, not illogical and frustrating.

pegi.synopsis: The content of this game is suitable for persons aged 18 years and over only. It contains: Extreme violence.

reviews.review:
++++++++++
1.Eerie Atmospheric.A noir indie masterpiece.
2.Great Puzzles.Not overly complex.
3.Superb Ambient Sound.The lack of music enhances the oppresive mood.
----------------

igdb.name: Titan Souls
igdb.summary: Between our world and the world beyond lie the Titan Souls, the spiritual source and sum of all living things. Now scattered amongst the ruins and guarded by the idle titans charged with their care, a solitary hero armed with but a single arrow is once again assembling shards of the Titan Soul in a quest for truth and power.
igdb.storyline: Titan Souls tells the story of a nameless warrior’s quest to bring down the ancient titans with nothing but a single, indestructible arrow. There are no lesser classes of enemies, no crafting, no grinding and no side quests -- just you and the two dozen titans scattered throughout the land awaiting your challenge.

reviews.review:
Bought it on sale 75% off, I recommend if you are a casual player, to avoid this game.

You only have one arrow, you can only take one hit, there are no upgrades, there are no power ups, you are at full power when the game begins ( there's a demo if you want to try it ) 

The hook is this - everything dies in one hit, sounds easy right?
You shoot your arrow, and you have to run over to it to pick it up, or call it back by holding the fire button.
You can damage some bosses by recalling your arrow ( some bosses require it ) 

And this is where it gets frustrating, since every boss dies in one hit, the challenge comes in finding out HOW to hit them.
The slime boss splits every time you hit it, the brain inside one of the jellies is the weak spot. You can roll, and run and avoid that slime ( because it slows you down ) 

Once you beat the first four bosses, the game REALLY opens up into a huge expansive world with tons of bosses to fight, and the difficulty never lets up.

It is very well made, the sprites are beautiful - the concept is unique to a point ( no pun intended ) 

Originally I hated this , but after I beat the first four bosses, and saw what came next - i was hooked.
Needs an option for changing the keybindings. Don't just tell me you strongly recommend a game pad. It's artificially hard for this reason.

do you like to die

over and over again




perfect

I thought this game looked neat when it was on sale, picked it up for like 3 bucks lmao.

284 deaths later, i want to bang my head on my desk, but instead i restarted to get the achievements.
10/10 would beat myself in the dick w/ controller again.

Game was too simple to be fun in my opinion. Some bosses were fun, others were just strange and had attack patterns that didn't make sense at all. The spawn point is too far away from bosses later in the game, so you spawn so far back you spend more time walking to the bosses than you do actually fighting them.

After having watched other people play it, I have to say this is a really good game overall if you are into this sort of constantly fighting difficult bosses type game. Also, the art style and music are beautiful.

But after barely beating the first 4 bosses (some of which I cheesed), and being destroyed many times by the next few I tried, I have to say this is not my kind of game. I might try playing it again here and there, but nothing continual as the constant deaths and walking back gets annoying quickly. Also, the controls are absolutely terrible. I had to get a key remapping program just to be able to function properly, and I suggest doing the same.
The long walks back from the respawn ruin what could be an awesome game.

Played this a long time ago when it first released. Never payed.
Paying now that I see it on Steam and have funds, you deserve it. Fantastic game.

Art is okay but doesn't carry it.
Concept is okay but Shadow of the Colosus did it, and much better, a long time ago.
Music is passable.

This is not worth the money at all, there are far better pixel art/ boss fight/ exporation games out there.

Regret spending the money and I got it on sale.

Really hard, but also pretty addictive. I wanted to smash my computer monitor, but I kept playing anyway. Nice graphics, smooth controls, very simple but very fun.

To simple

This is a long'un.


The first boss I fought, I died roughly 7 times, despite knowing what I had to do right away. But each time I played it I learned something new about the boss that helped me ultimately defeat it. Then after it fell, I thought it was odd that nothing seemed to change. No new unlocks, weapons, or mechanics. Nothing. Then I awoke the second boss and BAM! I'm dead. I had to beat two other bosses to cool down before trying him again, and he still destroyed me several times first. I made my friend play it, and he beat it his first go. 

As someone who has played Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past, Shadow of the Colossus, Dark Souls, and other similar, grueling, bloody difficult, boss-centric games, I can definitely say this is not a rip off of any of those (even if one of the fights is almost directly taken from Shadow of the Colossus). This is an homage, and a good on at that. 

It gets the atmosphere down perfect, plopping you into a world that is both interesting and silent about its own origins, leaving you, the player, to do your best to infer what the hell this world is. This simplicity in world and the equally simple nature of you mission - find and kill bosses - is also reflected in the design and mechanics. You can move around, and you have two buttons. One fires your bow and summons your arrow back, and one causes you to perform a dodge-roll. When you hold the roll button you run faster. That is it. But it is the way those mechanics intaract with the world around you that is both so interesting AND crucial to defeating bosses. 

Oh and as an after thought, the designs of the bosses (most of them anyway) are interesting, but they are just as simple as you. You die in one hit, but so do they. Finding their weak spot and figuring out how best to approach and hit that weak spot is not only fun, but fitting with the simple motif of "less is more". 

I payed 3.75 for this, instead of 15. But, I would gladly pay that full price for this game, which not only offers me fun and interesting boss fights that I want to beat no matter how times I die, but keeps me going just to see what the next one looks like. I am not even finished (stuck on that plant monster in the trailer. 30+ deaths and counting) and I still can't wait to jump back in and see what else this game has to throw at me!

By the way, this game is hard and you will die a lot. Just letting those of you who get easily frustrated know. I was dying and shouting "GOD DAMMIT! I HATE THIS! THIS GAME IS SO GOOD!"

This game was an amazing experience. It's far from perfect, but i'm so happy i played it. The good things are good enough for me to ignore the bad things now that i'm done with it, but frustration was present during my playthrough.

The concept: 
There are only boss fights, you die from one hit and so does the boss if its weak point is hit. This makes it a very challenging game

Good things: 
-Most bosses provide you with good clues about its weak point and how to hit it as long as you are observant. Sometimes it even feels like you are playing some kind of skill-based puzzle. Once you figured out how to exploit a bosses weakness it becomes a quest for the perfect run to win. A perfect run might take like 5 seconds even though you've spent like half an hour on the same boss. Weird, but cool and unique.
-The music is amazing
-It's beautiful

Bad things:
-The world is built as if you are meant to explore it, but there is nothing to find really. All you want is to find the next boss, not mystical paintings on rocks that just acts like red herrings in the end. Looks cool though, i guess.
-Some bosses are hidden in unclear ways, which also adds to the bad things about the exploration.
-It's a top down-view in mostly 2d graphics. But some bosses uses 3d movement by moving in the air before attacking from above. This semi-3d movement sometimes becomes hard to read from a top-down perspective in an intense boss-fight. Causing you to feel like you died because you misread whether a spiky limp was in the air or not, or if a flying rock fist was slamming down or just moving

What could be improved?
Aside from the bad things mentioned, the boss fights feels a bit short once you actually beat them. BUT there is one boss that has multiple phases. Each phase is still won with just one perfect strike, but each perfect strike causes the boss to take on a new form, so it became longer while not breaking the games concept. This fight was so damn amazing and i wish there was more of it!

Fun game, reminds me a lot of Shadow of the Colossus. Every enemy dies in one hit, and it's fun to try and figure out how to hit their weak point.

Two big problems though. 

1, you will die a lot and although that's fine, each death means about a 15 second walk back to the arena. I find this really grating as you also die in 1 hit, and you will spend a lot of deaths learning a boss's weaknesses. 

2, Many bosses I've fought so far (about 5 out of the 8) are very confusing initialy as what you need to even do. This can be frustrating when you spend 15-20 seconds getting to their arena, only to die immediately because it's unclear what you're supposed to be doing. Part of the fun I admit is figuring this stuff out, but when it's been 20 deaths it isn't fun anymore.

All in all I recommend the game, it's fun, but it could be vastly improved with better checkpoints.

If your main complaints about Hyperlight Drifter is that the ammunition wasn't limited *enough*, that the dash move was *too* responsive, that the sword was in the game at all, and you found the constant sense of exploration and discovery annoying and wished you could just select the boss fights from a menu, well, maybe you'll like this game.

Nooooooo... I gotta walk all the way back, everytime I die. 

If only I could rebind the keys to something that won't give me carpal tunnel... Wait nvm I can't. 

Wish I wouldn't need a gamepad to play this, playing on keyboard feels like ass. There is no weight to any of the movement and having only 8 directions to choose from is aggravating.

If you don't have access to a gamepad, don't play this game. Its not worth dying hundreds of times due to a lack of hardware.

appDetails.name: Titan Souls
appDetails.detailed_description:
Between our world and the world beyond lie the Titan Souls, the spiritual source and sum of all living things. Now scattered amongst the ruins and guarded by the idle titans charged with their care, a solitary hero armed with but a single arrow is once again assembling shards of the Titan Soul in a quest for truth and power.

Colossal Titans: Explore the ancient ruins of your forefathers and uncover extraordinary and unique titans, each with their own savage attacks and hidden weakness. Find and exploit their faults to slay the beasts and consume the primeval power that lies within them.

Simple Combat: Loose your solitary arrow at the monstrous titans and summon it back to your hand to unleash another forceful strike. Dash and run from the titan’s attacks but do not fear death, as it is both inevitable and plentiful in Titan Souls.

Arcane Secrets: This realm is not without its secrets. Long forgotten titans are hidden in the shadows and prowling through the furthest corners of the land – find them, destroy them, and take their souls for your own to discover the true extent of the power that resides here.

Titan Souls | Digital Special Edition

The Titan Souls Digital Special Edition includes a digital artbook, world map, full original soundtrack and desktop backgrounds. All files can be found in the game's folder on your hard drive.

igdb.name: Spelunky
igdb.summary:
Spelunky is a cave exploration / treasure-hunting game inspired by classic platform games and roguelikes, where the goal is to grab as much treasure from the cave as possible. Every time you play the cave's layout will be different. Use your wits, your reflexes, and the items available to you to survive and go ever deeper! Perhaps at the end you may find what you're looking for... 
 
Don't be afraid to die! But also don't be afraid to live! Happy Spelunky-ing!

reviews.review: This game has very nice artwork. It is quite difficult because when you die you have to start from the beginning. There are lots of things you can learn to make yourself better at this game. Once you know the tricks you can become a master.

A perfect old-school co-op arcade-style roguelike platformer with: polished design, deep mechanics, balance, challenge, interesting randomization with events and variety.  Up to 4 players locally with no login on one game license.  Simple to learn with a high skill-cap (do you dance with the Ghost?).  Rock-solid bug-free app.  Co-op is complex and dangerous.  The co-op ghost mechanic which occurs when a co-op person dies and becomes a ghost until a resurrection coffin is found is valid and interesting and surprising and deep (a co-op ghost can fend off the Ghost indefinitely).  100 hours in, I still have a lot to learn.  Has a tiny number of items compared to similarly-amazing games like The Binding of Isaac, but is no less great for it.  I am a child of the 80's and this is would have been a legend had it released then.

Try the original free pixelated version if you have questions.  It contains all of the foundations of this game except 4-player co-op.

Disregard my play time record on steam. I have poured hundreds of hours into Spelunky on xbox. This game is hard, unforgiving, frustrating, and overall an adventure. I've had over 1,000 playthroughs and about three wins total (not taking any shortcuts). The thing to keep in mind, especially before you purchase this game- is that Spelunky is a roguelike. The purpose of the game isn't to win; the purpose of the game is to try. I can't tell you how many times I've been in a run with a whole arsenal of items at my disposal and the odds seemingly in my favor... and then I die in some stupid way. But once you get over the initial learning curve and develop a strategy that works for you- you'll learn to love the challenge. For me, I always killed the shopkeeper and used his shotgun to force my way through any situation. A run can last you anywhere from 10-20 minutes, and if you get super lucky and "git gud", you'll get to see where all those hours of failed runs would have got you had you survived: a notsohard boss fight and moment of realization that the game was always about the adventure, not the destination.

Basically, this game provides good replayability and a lot of frustration. What else would you expect from a roguelike? Oh, and one quick word of advice from a console peasant! Use a controller; the keyboard is harder to use... You'll see.

I want to like this game. I REALLY want to like this game. But there are small things here that I just can't get over.

Now first, the pros:

Minor gripes:

I want to say this might be bad luck, but I've had levels were there were 3-4 arrow traps along the same path, which was the needed one to get to the tunnel and leave, or maybe to rescue the damsel in distress. And yes I realise I can just drop something to trigger them, I also cant count how many times I've been fucked over by  something pushing me into them.

Like I said, just minor things I don't like. Now for some real issues I have.

Cons:

-There is a bug where if you close out of the game, by the red X, then the game still thinks that its running despite being closed. This becomes VERY annoying if your music isnt turned off, because you can't turn it off.

Look, I just wanna say: I can see why people like this game. I really do.
It's jus tnot for me. Thats why I reccomend this game, if it's for you.

Expectation: I'm a bad ass!
Reality: Oh God, I hate this fucking stupid game.
This game gonna fuck you in every possible way

(Hercules voice) DISAPPOOOOINTED!!

Description lies. Totally lies.

> "explore fantastic places filled with all manner of monsters, traps, and treasure. You'll have complete freedom while you navigate the fully-destructible environments and master their many secrets. To stay or flee, to kill or rescue, to shop or steal... in Spelunky, the choice is yours and so are the consequences!"

It's bullsh*t.

This game is not about exploring, not about collecting treasures, not about rescue – it's only about speedrun.

Actually, it's "Mario" - you have to reach exit in limited time (and you can kill enemies jumping on their heads!). The difference is only that when time is out, you don't immediately die but instead a huge invinsible ghost is spawned somewhere on level and chases you (and instakills you on touch). Oh, and another tiny detail – there is no timer on screen. So you never know how much time do you have.

In practice this means that you have to run to exit as fast as you can, only gathering things which are right on your way. Want to explore level? Want to reach that remote locked room with a lot of gems? Want to find a merchant to finally spend your money? Want to resque a traveller (to heal yourself)? Want to bring resqued traveller not to exit right before you but to Kali altar on the another end of level? Fine! Go there! And see how ghost is spawned right before the only exit from a room you just entered. Or before exit from level in the very corner of the map, so you can't bypass him anyhow. And then you die. Just because of random, that generated a deadlock situation.
"To stay or flee, to kill or rescue, to shop or steal"... – the choice is not yours, the choice belongs only to map generator.

Sure, with practice you'll definitely be able to fly through level fast and devastating as living tornado and will never reach time limit. Of course. But know what? IT'S NOT AN EXPLORING! It's a damn speedrun. Run, run, run, always remember about time. It's not the game I expected.

> "You'll have complete freedom while you navigate the fully-destructible environments and master their many secrets"

Yeah... complete freedom... time-limited complete freedom.

Oh, also about "fully-destructible environments". Well, they are destructible. With bombs. You have some limited amount of bombs, and you should find or buy more to keep yourself able to destroy environment. Because you are spelunker that CAN'T DIG (need to buy a special item for this). And the deeper you go, the more you'll need to use bombs only as weapon - because monsters are strong and traps are numerous and deadly (up to instakill, again). That is, in practice – forget about "fully-destructible environments", just run where you see a path – exit is ALWAYS available without need to destroy walls, only treasures and travellers can be completely locked up. So just run. Run, run, run.

So. If you, like me, came here to EXPLORE dungeons, crawling, digging and thinking how to better destroy walls to create optimal path – it's not the game you're looking for.
I don't say the game is bad (although I can't imagine what kind of masochist can like to run 5-10 minutes just to die from another oneshot). It looks very nice, it consumes your time as hell, and probably you can trully master it so there is a reason to play... it's not a BAD game.
But it totally deceives you with it's description. As a result – a big disappointment, because it's not that kind of gameplay which I expected. And because of disappointment I dislike it.

appDetails.name: Spelunky
appDetails.detailed_description:
Spelunky is a unique platformer with randomized levels that offer a challenging new experience each time you play. Journey deep underground and explore fantastic places filled with all manner of monsters, traps, and treasure. You'll have complete freedom while you navigate the fully-destructible environments and master their many secrets. To stay or flee, to kill or rescue, to shop or steal... in Spelunky, the choice is yours and so are the consequences!

Key Features


  • "Roguelike" Platforming - Randomly-generated, fully-destructible levels are dense with danger. Quick thinking and a deep understanding will keep you alive along the knife's edge!
  • Fill Your Journal - Track your progress with a dusty explorer's journal given to you by Yang, your mentor from another age.
  • Local Co-op - Up to 4 players can join up to help or hinder in madcap cooperative play.
  • Deathmatch - Unlock 72 diverse, deadly arenas to wage battle in against friends or bots.
  • The Daily Challenge - Each day a new set of levels is generated for the Daily Challenge, a unique mode where you only get one chance per day to compete online against the rest of the Steam community.
  • A Colorful Cast - A roster of 20 squishy explorers (16 unlockable) are waiting for you to make their greedy dreams come true!
  • Tough Love - You're going to die in all kinds of painful, hilarious, and surprising ways. But with each mistake you'll learn more about how Spelunky works and get that much closer to solving its deepest mysteries!

igdb.name: Battlesloths
igdb.summary:
Battlesloths is the fast-paced local multiplayer competitive twin-stick shooter of your slothy dreams. Compete with up to 4 human players or play against AI sloths should you be short of friends. Use a myriad of weaponry, each with their own strategies, to destroy your enemies in a quest to collect the most pizza.

With 12 unique weapons, 7 game modes, customizable battle settings, team vs. options, free for all, a nuke and more hats than you can fit on 50 sloths heads; you’ll have plenty to do as you train to become the ultimate gun-toting, hoverboarding, pizza eating sloth on the block! Revel in the silliness of the slothpacalypse, shoot everything that moves and start hoarding pizza!

humbleBundle.human_name: Golgotha Run, a Dark Future Novel by Dave Stone

igdb.name: Hack, Slash & Backstab
igdb.summary: Hack, Slash & Backstab is a 1 - 4 player arcade dungeon crawler with a twist! Work together as warrior, rogue, wizard and archer to survive a dangerous world. But only one player will be crowned the winner: it becomes a fight to the death, as betrayal and backstab become the tools of choice.

reviews.review:
Very simplistic game, but still enjoyable. Recommend playing with friends than alone, just to add to chaos and laughs. Music and sounds are fine. Graphics are pretty good for what it is.
Definitely worth the price tag is you want a casual game to mess around in with friends. Very gauntlet feel.

Only issue I had might have been due to my controller. As I use a PS4 controller, whenever I click join it brings in two characters and I have to move one off the platform to drop one of them. Not sure if an intentional feature or not. Not really a big issue either way.

I would like to see more modes added to it aside from the only co-op+VS mode.

I don't dislike the game but I can't bring myself to recommend it to the steam community.

I learned of the game through a story on NPR - a group/class project at a local University in my area.  I'm also always looking for good local-coop games to play together with my two boys.

Technically, the game is flawless.  Smooth fast graphics, highly responsive, no lag, great sound and pretty pictures.   Also, I've always enjoyed rogue-like games and this was a nice twist.

Unfortunately, that's about it in terms of gameplay.  Not to be crass, but it feels like a school group project - a roguelike game made by committee that's a mile wide and an inch deep.  Like any game, once the pretty pictures wear off, there needs to be something of substance behind it.  Even the original nethack games had a leveling system - and with good reason!  You need some reason to keep playing and go for just one more dungeon.   More than 4 monsters and a few bosses would be a good start. 

I guess it's easier to give a school grade for solid graphics and technical savvy then it is to judge depth or playability.  And having the goal of publishing to Steam is a good carrot to motivate students to meet a deadline I suppose. 

My boys (8 & 10 yo) had fun with the novelty of the game for about 15 minutes.  But once they realized that there was only more of the same around each corner, they lost interest quick - and so did I.

Plays sort of like an indie Diablo. Liked all of the classes; you have to experiment and find one to suit your playstyle. I thought I'd like the Knight the most, but so far the Archer is my favorite. It's not as good close up, but if you can get some distance and find an area to bottleneck the enemies, it's good for crowd control. Generally, I go room to room, then try and find either a boss, treasure, or an area to keep them at bay so I can rack up health drops. Overall it's definitely fun, but I think it's more suited towards playing with your friends. It's very difficult to play by yourself, but still fun. The music really puts a punctuation on everything and is really great. I'd love to see a few more modes and levels eventually, maybe even a campaign like a Spyro-esque mode where you teleport to different worlds and fight their bosses, but I understand that's a lot more work for the future. Great game and definitely recommending.

Start game.
Select a class (out of 4).
Start session (solo or coop).
Fight enemies and a boss.
Find the portal to end session.
Whoever entered the portal won that game session.

Very basic gameplay.
No looting of better equipment.
No leveling.
No skill point system or talent tree.
No character customization.
No reward for 'Winning'.
No nothing. Just hit enemies with basic attacks and find the portal to end game session.

I cant really recommend this, as this offers no replay value other than to first test it solo and then test it in coop and you kinda just wanna find that refund option.

As others have said, it's not awful, but it just doesn't feel like much of a purchasable game to me. It was the same frustrating map, and the skills aren't that diverse. It needs some sort of thing that makes me want to play it, some sort of reward or story. Unfortunately, it has neither, and I just can't bring myself to even ask my friends to buy it.
$5 was not worth it. Waste of money. Should be $2 at most.

appDetails.name: Hack, Slash & Backstab
appDetails.detailed_description:
Hack, Slash & Backstab is a 1 - 4 Player Couch Co-Op Dungeon crawler, that pits players against a dungeon teeming with evil creatures. Players collect powerful items, perform special attacks, and fight boss monsters in a quest to find the portal that will let them leave the dungeon. The catch is...only one of them can escape. Players will battle one another to be the one who survives, but making the mistake of betraying your “friends” too soon may cost you your life. Hack, Slash & Backstab - where the dungeon is dark, and your friends aren’t friendly.


- DISCLAIMER: Requires controllers in order to play, not compatible with mouse and keyboard

Key Features:
- 1 to 4 player couch co-op action
- Fast paced, arcade style dungeon crawler
- 4 unique playable characters
- Powerful items to aid in your quest
- Challenging boss encounters
- Procedurally generated dungeons, making for a new journey every round
- Friendly fire is always on, wait for the right moment, then betray your team

igdb.name: Crawl
igdb.summary: Crawl is the local multiplayer dungeon crawler where your friends control the monsters! It’s bullet-hell beat-em-up meets old-school RPG, in an arcadey party-game for up to 4 players. One player is the hero, exploring a randomly generated dungeon full of traps and monsters - all controlled by the other players. If you slay the hero you take their place and it’s your turn to crawl! Then it's a race to gain enough XP and loot to reach the final battle, where it's all on one as the other players collectively control the hulking final boss!

It contains: Realistic looking violence

reviews.review: This is the kind of game that makes me wish I had friends to play with
had some fun with friends. I found it optimal to play 3-player games, anything more or less becomes too much or too boring.

Very fun, and fast paced. Wishing it had a dedicated server, but local LAN/split screen is still decent (if you have friends). Otherwise, it's fun to fight your way to each boss battle. 

Not a whole lot to complain about with this title. Loved it from the moment I laid eyes on it. Love the retro aesthetic with the modern play style.

the bad reviews are so depressing, invite ur mom or something dawg

igdb.name: Freeway
igdb.summary:
Freeway is a video game designed by David Crane for the Atari 2600 video game console. It was published by Activision in 1981. One or two players control chickens who can be made to run across a ten lane highway filled with traffic in an effort to "get to the other side." Every time a chicken gets across a point is earned for that player. If hit by a car, a chicken is forced back either slightly, or pushed back to the bottom of the screen, depending on what difficulty the switch is set to. The winner of a two player game is the player who has scored the most points in the two minutes, sixteen seconds allotted. The chickens are only allowed to move up or down. A cluck sound is heard when a chicken is struck by a car. Comparisons are often made to Frogger, which has also features crossing a street filled with moving vehicles. Similarities did help sales when Frogger was popular in the arcades and a home version was not yet available. 
 
Freeway was made available on Microsoft's Game Room service for its Xbox 360 console and for Windows-based PCs on August 18, 2010.

igdb.name: SOMA
igdb.summary:
SOMA is a sci-fi horror game from Frictional Games, creators of the groundbreaking Amnesia and Penumbra series. 
 
The radio is dead, food is running out, and the machines have started to think they are people. Underwater facility PATHOS-II has suffered an intolerable isolation and we’re going to have to make some tough decisions. What can be done? What makes sense? What is left to fight for? SOMA is a sci-fi horror game from Frictional Games, the creators of Amnesia: The Dark Descent. It is an unsettling story about identity, consciousness, and what it means to be human.
igdb.storyline:
The radio has gone silent on PATHOS-2. As isolation bears down on the staff of the remote research facility, strange things are happening. 
 
Machines are taking on human traits and alien constructions have started to interfere with routine. The world around them is turning into a nightmare. 
 
The only way out is to do something unimaginable.

pegi.synopsis:
The content of this game is suitable for persons aged 16 years and over only.
It contains: Realistic looking violence - Strong language

reviews.review:
Life, consciousness, purpose and what it means to be human. SOMA is an exceptional masterpiece.

Quite a few of the single elements in this game are probably similar to things you have seen, read or watched somewhere else before. There is not all that much to do in terms of gameplay and puzzles. The levels are quite small by today´s standards and everything is mostly linear. It is not very challenging to finish and you will likely spend not much more than 10 hours to see the story through.
    
After an innocuous intro level you awake in an atmospheric and slightly creepy little dungeon (which initially looks and feels similar to a deserted vault from a Fallout game) and start to find out where you are and what has happened. 

This game achieves something that is very rare. Before you know it, you seamlessly become immersed into a story that makes you question the very fundamentals of what it means to be alive, conscious, human and to have a purpose in life. Amazingly, this is done without the slightest hint of grandiosity, nudging, judgement or lengthy exposition on deep philosophical principles – just by exploring the world and discovering piece by piece where you are and what has happened as you move on to find a way out from the place.

Tl; dr:  SOMA is a deeply moving and profound experience, delivered effortlessly in an almost minimalistic way. Outstanding.

Wow, what a story! Definitely one of the best gaming experiences I've had. A quality sci-fi horror game.

+ Story
+ Atmosphere
+ Great controller support (played using Xbox One controller)
+ Voice acting
+ Just the right game length
+ No cheap jumpscares

- Performance (stutters here and there, but nothing too serious)

Although I must say, [i] I really hate the deep ocean[/i]...

[b] 10/10 [/b] - Absolutely worth a playthrough!

The horror elements and stealth gameplay were a profound step down from Amnesia, and somewhat disappointing. 

The setting and narrative more than make up for this. I can't remember the last time I played through a game in more or less one sitting, at each moment desperate to see what occurred next.

If you derive any enjoyment whatsoever from story-driven games with some light horror and stealth elements, do not hesitate to buy this game.

A profound psychological horror experience with Frictional Games' usual fantastic pacing that you could make an example out of, paired with top-tier voice acting and a mature story set in a transhumanist dystopia, that will grip you from start to end and leave you wanting for more. A landmark of its genre.

What a game! This was actually better than I expected. I really loved the story and it got me thinking at some points.

Also all the monsters and all were creepy as hell, and the way they appeared at some points really got me some goosebumps. The overall atmosphere of the game is so dark and creepy, and I loved that. It's kinda like scifi-horror version of BioShock. Just by the fact that you're under the sea got me anxious lol. But anxious in a good way.

SOMA has pretty much like Amnesia style of gameplay. I don't know is it just me, but there were parts where you were kinda left on your own to think what you should do. Kind of like where you should go and what you should be doing. Because there are no objective markers or anything. You just kinda have to figure everything out by yourself.

In general, I really like this game and I would recommend this to anyone who is into scifi-horror and post-apocalyptic stuff.

Thank god for developers like Frictional Games, that are willing to take the risk and time to explore more complex themes and ideas. SOMA isn't perfect, but once the screen fades to black for the last time it makes up for any deficit. It sets an impossible standard for most indie developers.

This was not the game I was expecting. If, like me, you have only glimpsed some early build trailers, then the design has clearly changed. Placed underwater, amongst the remains of humanity, you must come to grips with almost a century of change, and ultimately redefine the term human. Talking robots, mechanized humans and corrupted marine life all play their role in convincing you that something has gone horribly wrong. 

Frictional maintain a number of elements from their previous outings, including physics based puzzles. Almost any object can be grabbed, dropped and thrown; levers can be pulled; wheels can be twisted; doors pulled or pushed open. The concept lends a welcome tactile nature to the story which, sadly, falls back on a familiar trope: your all alone, EXCEPT for a voice to guide you. While you identify the owner of the voice, and ultimately take on their objective as your own, it still feels like a commitment to revealing the story through environment and atmosphere would have strengthened the isolation, making searching out information a puzzle in itself. 

The look and setting of SOMA will bring obvious comparisons to Bioshock, but it's tenuous link at best. Skulking through the confined, industrialized corridors of Pathos II feels far removed from the Art Deco inspired, living spaces afforded to Rapture. No guns and plasmids, only exploring and hiding. 

Worth a special mention is the sound design, music and voice acting. Certain games lend themselves to headphones more than others, and you would be doing a disservice not to use them in this case. The effect is universally excellent in creating a sense of place, whether the groan of stressed metal or the muted, calm of the seafloor. 

Previous Frictional releases have relied on enemies to provide constant tension and scares, leaving you cowering in darkened corners. SOMA's mechanized enemies don't appear as frequently, and tend to be solo when they do, but I personally found them to be frustrating. My main issue was their completely random nature. In one example I was left with the enemy blocking my only way forward, unresponsive to sound or light, and refusing to budge until I ran at it, died and restarted past that point. While they are fitting to the story and environment, I couldn't help but feel they may not have been necessary, and instead the developer felt pressured to include them.

There are some other issues, I experienced, that may or may not concern others. Loading times are looooong (up there with The Witcher 3), with intermittent loading occuring at strange intervals. Pacing is slower in the first half than the more compelling second. Objectives are not marked which leads to wandering and backtracking trying to find items and puzzles to solve. 

The best test of the success of an idea is how it stays with you afterward. Like Life Is Strange, SOMA has remained with me since finishing, debating the choices I made and trying to reconcile the events into chronological order. It's Frictional's best story yet, offering a rich message that never takes away from the terror of playing. In fact, that message questioning what it means to be human, is SOMA's most terrifying element. The game isn't perfect, none are, but if an amazing story, wrapped in an absorbing atmosphere and sprinkled with puzzles is your thing, then it's an easy choice.

Wow. The story and ideas contained in this game are first class. Mature questions are raised on "existence" and what it means to be human. Are we simply a collection of electrical impulses? Can and should our “self” be cloned? Soma is worth playing through for the story alone.

The atmosphere is suitably chilling and claustrophobic, although the levels are somewhat linear in design. The monsters encounter system copies the Alien Isolation idea but doesn’t quite pull it off well enough. Getting past a monster can feel frustrating at times, but overall it doesn’t detract too much from the gameplay.

The voice acting is excellent and the whole experience feels like an interactive movie. Totally recommended to fans of creepy, intelligent science fiction.

I rarely write reviews even though I read them a lot (sorry), but after playing SOMA, I felt I had to speak up.

I've been playing video games since Pong came out (yes, I'm THAT old).
In the past I primarily played RPGs and dungeon crawlers because that's all there was. I've never liked racing or sports games or Mario-style platformers and side-scollers.
Most of the time now, I play FPS or FPS/RPG games - like Half-Life, FEAR, Dead Space, Prey (original and new), Fallout 4, Borderlands, Wolfenstein....you get the idea - a little plot, a lot of action and killing (yay!).

Since I've enjoyed many of the 'horror' style games, I recently tried Layers Of Fear and thoroughly enjoyed it - but that's for another review.

Here's the thing - usually the stories are rehashes of every other game - Bad Mega Corporation created some nasty goop and tested it on humans thereby making monsters? Ok, yeah, again, fine.
Aliens came here to colonize the planet and brought the goop with them? Sure, of course, I know this one.
The character acting, while sometimes quite good, still leaves me not caring one bit about them. Gotta kill a 'partner' to save another? Uh-huh, why not, who cares? 

As another example, I started playing Elex and I'm about 20 hours into it. I finally got to the point where my character was
able to protect himself from many other creatures, but it rapidly became an exercise in making way too many 'moral choices'.
I stopped playing because it wasn't fun or exciting - it became a chore. Work your way through the dialog tree, then get some action for a few minutes, then find another character and spend 10 minutes working another dialog tree. Hours of walking and talking. Yuk.
In a similar way, I couldn't play Fallout 3 because it was just talk talk talk talk talk do something talk talk talk...

SOMA is not like that - at all. It's more linear, well structured, well written, and well acted. It can be creepy as hell,
but mostly it's dark, lonely, sad, and thought provoking. I know that doesn't make it sound good or fun, but it really is.
There's no dialog tree - it's scripted so talking to another character means listening to them have a conversation.
It's not a totally original plot line (what is?) but it takes a different philosophical angle on a fairly common 'things went wrong' idea. This helps, I think - it keeps it familiar enough to be comfortable while still pushing you to think about something more than just where the next demon is.

I found something different with SOMA. While the acting was mostly quite good (some characters much better than others), it was the dialog and basic plot that I found intriguing - Can you still be human without your flesh and blood body?
As I approached the end, I actually had some feelings for the characters. At one point you have to decide how to handle a
dying character, one that you just met, and I found it way more emotional than I ever expected. At the very end, I was surprised that I was actually sad for the main character and sad the game ended.

OK, enough said about plot - if you check the discussions, you'll see pages of actual conversations discussing the philosophical implictions that SOMA presents, unlike I've seen for most games.

One more thing to note - I've been a SCUBA diver since 1974, and this is by far the best underwater representation I've seen.
There's no attempt to make it look like Finding Nemo (bright colors to look fun) - colors are muted and pale unless a light is shined directly on them, currents push you around, the coral growth is varied between a few years and decades, light doesn't travel far, and water is full of life no matter how small. Clearly, whomever did the design work has spent time diving, diving deep, and diving at night (or at least researching it well). I have only one criticism - moving underwater is still more laborious than shown, but you can't run from a monster if can't 'run' !

So, if you want a creepy but thought-provoking experience, try it.

Ever wanted a horror game where you win, but you aren't sure you win?  Where you saved the day but may have ended all days?  Just who are you anwway?  Are you the hero?  Are you the villian?  Are you even human?   (Best played in the dark with headphones, and well worth the price).

The gameplay is good, if not quite so scary as Amnesia. No complaints.

But the real standout is the story. The heavily philosophical elements made me think of the [i]Blade Runner[/i] films, but with an important difference. In [i]Blade Runner[/i] you are asked: is this new being a human also? How much do you have to add to a machine to make it human? In [i]SOMA[/i] the additive becomes subtractive: how much can be taken away from a human and leave them still human?

Also the sound design is great.

Basically, soma sells itself as a survival horror game. Something akin to outlast or alien isolation, (which are two games that show the true experience of immersion and interest in the plot through subtle themes and methodical gameplay) but Soma does the exact opposite. Instead of starting slowly, methodically and predictably, soma starts by thrusting upon the player a crazy turn of events which is immersive at first since we get to learn from the perspective of the protagonist who's just as lost as we are, but in the first 3 hours of gameplay the mystery is explained and the rest of the plot is spoon fed to you by the game's main supporting character. It seems at first to be quite scary, but immediately transitions into "isn't this existential stuff DEEP?" And oversells this, again and again to the point where it feels like I've puked in my mouth and swallowed it.

The plot is basically "go to place to complete game, get past interruptions and don't die." That's it, there's nothing else to it. Instead of feeling like "oh what an adventure this will be!" after the prologue, it's more like "I have to move this slowly for the rest of the game?" The "puzzles" are either easy and a bit of fun or overly annoying to the point where I have to alt-tab to google chrome and figure out what to do. The survival horror aspect is arguably the weakest part of the game. Slow-moving or stupid monsters that can either be easily evaded by, wait for it, STANDING STILL or even more easily outrun in some cases. Soma ISN'T scary in the slightest. The monster design is basic and uninteresting, the enemy AI is predictable and not stimulating and the atmosphere of the entire game doesn't make one feel unsettled or scared in any way. Near the halfway point I felt entirely annoyed and bored by the enemies, whereas in Outlast or alien isolation, my first instinct on hearing footsteps was to run and hide in hopes I can live long enough to progress. Not to see the next cutscene that's supposed to "make me feel something."

There is the "existentialist" point to the game and this is also arguably the weakest part. Basically, the protagonist is a robot that used to be human and is currently stuck in an underwater facility and he's trying to get out. Without spoiling anything, there's several points where you have to choose to destroy a simulated consciousness, and the characters seem to be totally uninterested and simply react to the realization that it's happening, without much actual input. Anyway, not being a complete twat, I chose not to kill the simulated people. I thought there would be some sort of payoff but there's literally no difference in the ending you get. As for the "philosophical" parts, it's like rehashing how to solve 2+2 after the first time the plot demands it. "robots with consciousness. Are they human?" Yes, no, whatever the hell you want, even if you haven't read any philosophy it's not hard to understand the idea of consciousness and it doesn't leave you feeling any different after you finish the game.

While I can appreciate this kind of narrative in a game, but Soma just takes itself too seriously, acting like it's the only thing in existence to quiestion what it means to be human. It's like a bag of movie theater popcorn. Nice at first, but after a little more than halfway through you get a bit sick. Soma's interesting at first, but loses it's complexity very quickly and isn't at all interesting after the fact but keeps up the act like it's a dancer who's completely forgotten the act and ends up being insultingly mediocre before the ending that just sort of "happens" and doesn't raise any questions besides "oh what a cliffhanger! I wonder what happens next!" because it doesn't matter. I rate this game 5/10.

SOMA is a game which is kind of inspired by dead space. But this game is very true in its way and the story is very confusing until we reach a certain level. This is not exactly an horror game like amnesia or outlast. This is very thrilling and keeps your nerves up throughtout the game.
The sound mixing is one of the best pros of the game it gives you a sense of fear throughout the game.
The gameplay is simple as expected.
The concept of the game is good and the ending is also well done.
Those who love to play an game which keeps your nerves up, go for SOMA without any doubt. Don't expct it to be a regular horror game type, its not. The story is also crisp and short.
Enjoy the game!!!!!!

Would become a transgender scuba diver again.

10/10

So when I bought this game I was sort of expecting a horror game. Turns out it is really not, so if that's the picture you've gotten so far then let me destroy that for you. Don't get me wrong: It has it's creepy and scary moments but no jumpscares or extremely scary tense situations like you'd have them in regular horror games. If you play this in the dark you don't really get scared at a single point during the game, some parts even felt more like an adventure game than a horror game.
Instead SOMA is an extremely story heavy game which it does really well. Plays a bit like those interactive novels but in a good way.
The ending is especially well thought out and really makes you wonder what is real and what isn't. Didn't expect the plot to turn this way but I am very positively surprised after having finished it.

What I also really think is positive about the game is the way how you can actually save when you exit and you continue right at the point where you've left while the loading screen quickly briefs you on how the story progressed so far and what your next task is.

The only downsides I could find to this game were the god damn f*cking monsters. I found they were EXTREMELY unnecessary and just immersion breaking. Yes I get that you need at least [i]some[/i] gameplay in your game, but they are more often than not just frustrating to deal with. Some of them are extremely easy to get around like a monster in the server room which was very easy to deal with, while others (especially the last two) are extremely f*cking obnoxious and annoying to deal with. So annyoing in fact, I couldn't be bothered to deal with them anymore so I just looked for walkthroughs on the internet literally just because it annoyed me to such an extend. I just wanted to progress the story further which I got really invested in really fast that these monsters seemed like a sh*tty excuse to throw obstacles at you and slow your progress down. Getting annoyed after your 3rd death to a monster already is just a generally bad sign. They were supposed to be immersive but broke my immersion more than anything else in the game.
I'd recommend playing this game on the easy mode where monsters don't kill you to keep your frustration to a minimum. 

Other than that I can really recommend the game for you. It was a lot of fun to play and definitely worth the money.

To call this a mere game would be an insult, this ladies and gentlemen is an EXPERIENCE.


Can't wait for Frictional Games' next (horrifying) project.
Really makes you think and wonder about life for quite a while. Overall, this game is about an 11/10 Jaden Smiths.

Good game.  Great graphics, some scary moments, and some genuinely unsettling choices to make.  My only criticisms would be that the final "big" choice seems to make no difference to the game's outcome, and that I didn't particularly enjoy having to play hide and seek with the monsters - that got boring.  I prefer to explore.

One of the greatest works of sci-fi horror you'll find in any form of media. Frictional manages to make players dread not only the game world and its inhabitants, but the greater questions of humanity and what it means to be alive.

From the great minds behind the spectacular and genre re-defining Amnesia comes another masterpiece in the field of psychological horror. You‘re put in the role of Simon Jarret, survivor of a car crash who has just woken up from a brain scan. But to your surprise, you woke up in a scientific outpost Pathos-II near the Mariana trench. The place is completely deserted and its corridors are filled with robots and other beings infected with cancerous rogue AI. Simon’s awakening is prefaced by a famous quote from Philip K. Dick: “Reality is that which, when you stop believing in it, doesn’t go away.” This quote sets the whole feeling you’ll get from the game’s story. One of SOMA’s many mysteries is how did you even got into the facility and into the year 2105 from your brain scan back in Toronto in 2015.
The amount of high quality narrative is astounding. The story itself would make a great book. Now you can live through the story and be a part of it. You will encounter some serious and profound questions of both an ethical and philosophical nature. The way we perceive the world around us, our reality, SOMA will make you question everything. A lot of dread and horror comes from the story and the things you don’t see and not from the encounters with enemies. SOMA doesn’t need cheap jumpscares and gore like many modern horror games to make you scared or even scream. You can feel how mature have Frictional Games became.
	The game itself plays well. The controls are intuitive and precise. One of Frictional Games’ trademarks is the interactivity they bring into their game worlds. You can pick up nearly everything, slide doors, open drawers and rummage through their contents. Of course, you will also run and try to hide from the horrors of Pathos-II. Encounters with your semi-organic enemies may, however, begin to be somewhat tedious for someone. You can’t fight them, the only thing you can try is to outsmart them and hide. You will cower in fear that your dark corner in which you’ve hidden yourselves will be discovered and even I found myself holding my breath not to give myself away. There are not many games that can do this.
	The graphics and sound are spectacular. Desolated hallways with mechanical tentacles protruding from the walls. Even the smallest detail getting the attention it deserves. Loud gnarls or high-pitched shrieks of the monsters. Everything makes up for the great and dreadful atmosphere of desperation and isolation.
SOMA is an ambitious work of science fiction which grapples with fundamental questions of consciousness, identity, and the relationship between the mind and the body. It will make you think about the way we perceive the world. The genre “Sci-Fi Horror” isn’t as exact as it may seem and it would be better to label it as a Philosophical Horror. It may not be for everyone due to its deep and mature story that makes you think. It feels weighty but never dry or ponderous thanks to an engaging and surprising story. I would definitely recommend it to anyone willing to think and ponder about life and its basic questions.

I am a huge fan of horror games and, to be honest, in my opinion this is one of the best games of this genre that I have played (if perhaps not the best). It manages to keep the balance by switching from mere suspenseful to terrifying experiences, letting you interact with the environment provided in such fashion as to let you grasp a deeply disturbing reality, but then again in general terms that is what Frictional Games is best at.

Let me then state what makes this game special among FG's works: As you get involved in the events that unfold, you realize that it's not only just monsters lying around and stealthing your way around them. It goes as deep as to provide a reflection on what makes one human, what is special about this "humanity" and in the worst scenario possible what is to be saved and what is to be left behind.

appDetails.name: SOMA
appDetails.detailed_description:
SOMA is a sci-fi horror game from Frictional Games, the creators of Amnesia: The Dark Descent. It is an unsettling story about identity, consciousness, and what it means to be human.

The radio is dead, food is running out, and the machines have started to think they are people. Underwater facility PATHOS-II has suffered an intolerable isolation and we’re going to have to make some tough decisions. What can be done? What makes sense? What is left to fight for?

Enter the world of SOMA and face horrors buried deep beneath the ocean waves. Delve through locked terminals and secret documents to uncover the truth behind the chaos. Seek out the last remaining inhabitants and take part in the events that will ultimately shape the fate of the station. But be careful, danger lurks in every corner: corrupted humans, twisted creatures, insane robots, and even an inscrutable omnipresent A.I.
You will need to figure out how to deal with each one of them. Just remember there’s no fighting back, either you outsmart your enemies or you get ready to run.

igdb.name: Infinifactory
igdb.summary:
Infinifactory is a sandbox puzzle game by Zachtronics, the creators of SpaceChem and Infiniminer. Build factories that assemble products for your alien overlords, and try not to die in the process. 
 
LIKE SPACECHEM… IN 3D! Design and run factories in a first-person, fully 3D environment. 
HISTOGRAMS ARE BACK! Optimize your solutions, and then optimize them more when you see how much better your friends did. 
VISIT EXOTIC ALIEN LOCALES! Explore a story-driven campaign with 30+ puzzles, audio logs, and more. 
BLOCKS THAT MOVE! Go beyond the campaign and push the limits of Infinifactory’s next-generation block engine in the sandbox. 
STEAM WORKSHOP INTEGRATION! Create, share, and play custom puzzles on Steam Workshop.

pegi.synopsis:
The content of this game is suitable for persons aged 12 years and over only.
It contains: Mild bad language

reviews.review:
This game puts you in the position of an alien abtuctee that is tasked with manufacturing various constructions from supplied materials for your new masters. Your role is to design and construct the "factory" to make each construction. In order to prove that your process works, you must deliver 10 perfect copies of the requested item to a "scanner" that validates that each copy delivered is correct. As you progress, you are given additional tools, more challenging conditions/restrictions and more complicated items to assemble. 

I first learned about this game through a YouTube reference/review from Mark Brown's Game Maker's Tool Kit (search for it and watch it) that put this game in the genre of "Problem-Solving" rather than "Puzzle-Solving". The distinction is worth noting. This game allows you to develop many potential solutions to each problem - and rates you on the time, moving part and space efficiency of your solution in the form of showing your performance relative to that of all the other Steam players.

You have unlimited design time to develop your solutions, and, apart from the final level, there are no practical time limits to how long your solution can take. There's even an achievement ("Subversive Engineering") for the running time of your (successful) solution being a really long time. 

Because you learn to use each new element one at a time, I never found the learning curve too intimidatingly steep, and the sense of reward when you solve a problem stage is strong. It is also possible to "finish" the game without completing all of the problem scenarios, in case there's one that you are having fits over.  

I've put over 150 hours into this game. Not because it's difficult to complete, although some of the campaign puzzles can really stretch your brain, but because I've wanted to "beat" the efficiency requirements to get all the achievements and develop better solutions.

Although there is Workshop support, I haven't done any of the Workshop levels yet. (I'm trying to work through other games in my library first...)

ladies and gentlemen. presenting the successor to the game that inspired minecraft. T.H.E. voxel-game codifier. this game will make you feel so smart one moment, incredibly stupid the next, make you ragequit in frustration, only to come back and FINALLY finish that stupid thing you wanted to fix!... and then ragequit again when something stupid goes wrong for seemingly no reason whatsoever...

this is a great way to get into Zachtronics puzzle games without needing an electronics or programming background.

Zachtronics creates games that ask the player to build a solution to solve a problem. I like these types of games and have written good reviews on a few Zachtronic games. I really want to write a good review of Infinifactory but I can't. 

My problem with this game is while it is okay to make something have to think to come up with a solution, there is such a thing as making it too hard to figure out. Right from the first training puzzle, the thing I felt was missing that was not the case in other Zachtronic games was the needed components to construct the solution. Shenzhen IO, TIS/100 and SpaceChem always had enough of the basic elements -- motion, a grabber, and a switch -- to complete the problem. With infinifactory, the grabber -- which in this case would be a clamp -- was missing and it was sorely needed on the third training puzzle where I had to weld a vertical two-block stack, then move the union to the transporter. There was simply no way to join two falling objects at different altitudes into a union and then at command move the union to the transporter. I spent a total of 2 and a half hours on that one puzzle before finally giving up and uninstalling.

When something becomes too hard to do, it stops being enjoyable. Infinifactory made the learning curve much too steep at the beginning and I truly feel it should have followed a more shallow incline demonstrated in the other games.
not my cup of tea

igdb.name: Screencheat
igdb.summary:
Screencheat is a chaotic split-screen multiplayer shooter that forces players to rethink the way they approach conventional multiplayer games. In the Screencheat arena, fast reaction times aren’t enough to keep you alive. When everyone is invisible, players will have to master the art of taking a not-so sneaky look at their opponent’s screens and working out where they are based on uniquely coloured areas of the map and distinctive landmarks.

Screencheat pays homage to iconic competitive first-person shooters such as Goldeneye, Perfect Dark and Halo, by blending the elements everyone loves about those games and shaking it up with its own unique take on the genre. When everyone’s used to playing by the rules, can you adapt to unconventional gaming quick enough to get the upper hand?

reviews.review: Great idea.

appDetails.name: Screencheat
appDetails.detailed_description:
Full Controller Support

Screencheat has full Steam Controller support including supporting multiple controllers to use touchpad mouse aiming.

Other controllers supported include Xbox 360, Xbox One, PS3 and PS4 controllers.


About the Game

Screencheat is the ridiculous split-screen shooter where everyone is invisible so you have to “screencheat” (Screencheat - verb: to look at your opponent’s screens. “Stop screencheating you cheater!”). Master a wide variety of one-hit kill weapons including a blunderbuss, a car engine that shoots bouncing plasma balls and a teddy bear loaded with explosives. Train your skills in the solo time trials then engage in fast and frantic combat with up to eight players locally on the couch or online. With colourful maps, unique modes and a huge number of customisation options including wacky mutators, Screencheat is the ultimate party FPS.


Ranging from the dependable Blunderbuss to the heroic Hobby Horse to the completely crazy Chefolet; a car engine that fires ricocheting energy balls, all are designed to deliver deadly satisfaction. Each weapon comes with its own unique advantages and disadvantages, encouraging wildly different play styles. These include not only the way a weapon shoots but also the 'tells' the weapon leaves such as the smoke from the blunderbuss or the trail of fire behind the Hobby Horse.


From traditional favourites such as Deathmatch to the completely unique Murder Mystery that challenges you to find and frag your specific target with a specific weapon. Play in teams or all against all. Challenge up to seven of your mates on the couch or online or a combination of both, the game is always split screen whether you are on or offline. When your friends aren't around, train your skills and learn the maps in the solo time trials or play against AI bots.


In the spirit of the best arena shooters you’ll spend time traversing 11 maps via air vents and trampolines until you’ve acquired your target and fragged them accordingly. Each map is designed with colour-coded areas as well as plentiful landmarks such as statues, paintings and furniture that allow you to quickly locate other players without being able to actually see them.


Inspired by games like Towerfall we've provided players with a highly granular level of customisation to play the game the way they want to. Choose which weapons you'll allow, how and when they can be swapped or reloaded, apply time limits, adjust the victory conditions, penalties and more. To really mix it up stack on some Mutators such as slow mode, low gravity or flappy jump.

appDetails.short_description: Screencheat is a ridiculous competitive split-screen first-person shooter where everyone is invisible, so players are forced to look at each other’s screens in order to win. Supporting both local and online multiplayer, combat in Screencheat is fast and furious with a wide variety of one-hit kill weapons.

appDetails.reviews:
“Screencheat is the Mario Kart of first person shooters and I absolutely mean that as a compliment”
Kotaku

“Easy going in tone but frantic and stressful by nature, Screencheat seizes on a single novel idea and builds an enjoyable couch shooter around it.”
7.8 – PC Gamer

“Glancing at someone else’s screen and knowing exactly where they are would be nigh-on impossible in most shooters, but Samurai Punk combats this through some smart level design.”
IGN

igdb.name: Gunmetal Arcadia Zero
igdb.summary: Unrest brews in the city of Arcadia, and a monstrous enemy approaches. As the young elf Vireo, you will heed the call of adventure: choose a weapon, choose a side, and rise to be the hero your city needs. Gunmetal Arcadia Zero features classic platformer action and world-class CRT simulation technology that evokes the aesthetics of past generations.

reviews.review:
Only NES kids will remember.

All in all this is quite the throwback to Zelda 2, Fanaxdu, Castlevanias and similar games back in those days, and the game does it well. The music is wonderful and the game isn't TOO hard or OVERLY cheap (as much as I hate 1 hit kill spikes, they aren't too plentiful).

It's short but it's pretty much the length of an NES game in which most of those you can finish in an hour or so. Got it on sale and I don't regret it.

appDetails.name: Gunmetal Arcadia Zero
appDetails.detailed_description:
Unrest brews in the city of Arcadia, and a monstrous enemy approaches. As the young elf Vireo, you will heed the call of adventure: choose a weapon, choose a side, and rise to be the hero your city needs. Gunmetal Arcadia Zero features classic platformer action and world-class CRT simulation technology that evokes the aesthetics of past generations.

From developer J. Kyle Pittman (Super Win the Game) and Minor Key Games (Slayer Shock) comes Gunmetal Arcadia Zero, an all-new action-adventure platformer drenched in glowing retro goodness.

  • Use blades, bombs, and a bevy of subweapons
  • Visit NPCs, buy and sell gear, and learn the lore of Arcadia
  • Fight your way through six stages jam-packed with baddies and bosses
  • Exquisite game feel — that's a thing!
  • NEW!! Speedrun mode tracks splits and records best times
  • World-class CRT simulation
    • Fully customizable
    • NEW!! Now with editable preset slots
  • Authentic 8-bit soundtrack
    • Over 40 minutes of original music
