igdb.summary: The Uncertain is an episodic story-driven adventure game set in a post-apocalyptic world. Experience the mysterious vibe of each of carefully explored locations, solve diverse puzzles, make fateful decisions and discuss intriguing matters to find out the whole truth being kept from you.

igdb.name: Cat Girl Without Salad: Amuse~Bouche
igdb.summary: Cat Girl Without Salad: Amuse-Bouche is the first taste of an exciting new game franchise by acclaimed developer WayForward (Shantae and the Pirate's Curse, DuckTales: Remastered). Follow Kebako, a cat-eared intergalactic bounty hunter, as she patrols the galaxies with her faithful companion (Squiddie) in search of ridiculous space criminals. The game combines classic shmup shooting with additional genres like puzzle, sports, arcade, platformer, rhythm, and RPG. Take on the galaxy's worst in a hilarious action shooter unlike anything you've ever played before!

igdb.name: Fran Bow
igdb.summary: Fran Bow is a creepy adventure game that tells the story of Fran, a young girl struggling with a mental disorder and an unfair destiny.

reviews.review:
Fran Bow is one of the most disturbing, morbid and yet fairytale-like adventure experiences I have ever experienced. While not being overly detailed or stunningly beautiful, the art design is fitting and especially the writing is an absolute contrast to the brutal game world, as it is absolutely innocent.

Wasn't too fond of the ending, but this is definitely one of the majorly interesting adventures released within the last couple of years. Definitely recommend to adventure fans with a knack for morbid themes. Not for the faint of heart or those easily disturbed.

I freaking love this girl, she is so cool. I don't care about my life very much, but I was worried sick about this girl. Despite knowing how this game works and ways to solve puzzles, I looked into a walk-through few times, just to be sure that Fran absolutely definitely won't die (it actually ruined some moments of the game for me, don't do that).
I was a little disappointed in the end, because, well, I knew that nothing can be perfect in Fran's life anymore, but I still hoped it freaking will, because she is so cool. She was the one in the game, who calmed me down, with her childish and innocent attitude. You know, I see a monster and my instincts are screaming: "we're DONE, Fran will die because of me", and then this little girl just says something like: "hello mr. Monster, how is your day?" She is the only reason I finished this game. She is super great.
A game that's not afraid to be special and immediately won my love.

O M G!! I am super confused and in love with this game right now! First chapter was super duper disgusting and with every chapter shits got crazier and crazier. Ending was kinda confusing and now I have so many questions and I am like OMG WHAT JUST HAPPENED. I love this game so much that I needed to write a review. I hope you guys try this one and play til the end it is really worth it

If you like any of the following, you'll enjoy this game: Labyrinth, Alice in Wonderland, Mirrormask, Neverending Story, etc etc.

Fran, a young girl, ends up in a twisted mental hospital, following the homicide of her parents. Who killed them and why? Fran is given a mysterious drug that lets her switch between realities and travel to new worlds parallel to ours. She sees weird monsters and imaginary friends. What is real? Is someone trying to kill her?

The game play is about 8 hours with 5 chapters, and very similar to The Silent Age, another point and click game that lets you switch between realities. The puzzles are not overly difficult but some of them are obtuse, requiring you to randomly click on things until something works.

There are some stupidly easy platform jumping and maze games, there's no fail state and some you can just skip over.

There's some very disturbing imagery (a la Hellraiser) and surrealistic horror. Lots of dead children, gore, and bad things happening to people. Not recommended for young children, but there's no sex or cursing. Fran remains optimistic even though really terrible things are happening to her. It falls into the realm of horror fantasy, and it's not all horrible. The middle bit is fantasy, and there's some murder mystery thrown in for good measure.

It was really fun to play, the art is delightful, and it'll leave you thinking. Highly recommended!

I really enjoyed this game. The ending was a bit abrupt but the overall game was really interesting. It was very philosphical and fun with it's mindgames and puzzles. Would have loved for it to be a bit longer.

An oddly delightful game.  Unusual subject matter with a dark storyline - don't be looking for a happy ending here.  At the same time, there's enough whimsy in the plot to keep you engaged and driven to finishing the game.   I enjoyed the experience and would buy a Fran Bow 2 should the option arise.

اللعبة رهبية 
هي خليط بين رعب نفسي وألغاز 
انصح به وبقوة للي ما جرب الألعاب اللي زي كذا
it's good game

Fran Bow is a great game. The game creators really created an excellent point and click horror game. The switching between worlds works perfectly fine and add some deep to the gameplay. You come accross some very disturbing situation and characters and in an horror game that's a plus. The puzzles and enigmas in the game are challenging but not too much to the point how you end up banging your head in search of a solution. 

Very Interresting story developed and you want to know more about Fran and her strange world. 
In the end some of the force of the game are also it's weakness. As I said the puzzles and enigmas aren't as challenging as some other games and it can be finished quickly (9 hours in my case) and at the end you're still craving for more, more of this disturbing world and mind of the little Fran Bow, more quests and for some maybe some more explenations ( The end is pretty open leaving you with maybe too many interpretations and not answered questions).

In the end even if the game price can be see as a little high for it's game time play, I still recommend it, and if you ever come across it during a sale and like horror games or disturbing point and click buy it with your eyes close. 

+ 
Excellent disturbing atmosphere and characters.
The quest and game mechanics are really well made.
If you like games with an open ending and everything up to your interpretation, this game ending is for you
A steal if you come across this game during a sale.

-
If you're up for a challenging game you will probably find it too easy.
Some more hours of play could have been welcome.
More answer about what is really happening in Fran mind and world. If you like games with a clear ending and answer to everything you could end up with more questions than answers at the end of it. 
You can find the price a little to high for all of it's content

appDetails.name: Fran Bow
appDetails.detailed_description:
Fran Bow is a creepy adventure game that tells the story of Fran, a young girl struggling with a mental disorder and an unfair destiny.
After witnessing the gruesome and mysterious loss of her parents, found dismembered at their home, Fran rushes into the woods, together with her only friend, Mr. Midnight, a black cat that Fran had previously received as a present from her parents.

In the forest, Fran goes into shock over the loss of her parents and when she recovers, she’s at Oswald Asylum, an oppressive mental institution for children, and Mr. Midnight is nowhere to be found.

After having a dream about her beloved cat, Fran decides to escape from the mental institution to find him and go back home to Aunt Grace, her only living relative.

Features

  • Story driven creepy psychological horror adventure game.
  • Unique and peculiar hand drawn 2D Art-Style and 2D animation.
  • Self administer medication to open the terrible hidden world that will help solve puzzles and find objects.
  • A big variety of puzzles designed with different levels of difficulty and specifically based on the story.
  • Three arcade inspired mini-games all with different art style to be part of the transitions in the story.
  • Interactive and occasionally playable pet cat, Mr Midnight.
  • 50+ interactive unique characters with unique personalities.
  • Original Soundtrack.

igdb.name: Tharsis
igdb.summary:
Tharsis is a turn-based space strategy game. With dice. And cannibalism. It puts you in control of humanity’s first manned mission to Mars, just as it’s struck by a micrometeoroid storm. You must guide your crew through disasters, food shortages, and the unforgiving nature of space — all while maintaining your sanity amidst cryptic signals and warnings from Mars.

Defy the odds, make the difficult decisions, and embark on the most important mission in human history.
igdb.storyline:
A mysterious signal originating from the Tharsis region of Mars set us on a frantic mission. Who sent it? And why? Impossible questions, but in them lie the key to humanity’s survival.

Now, millions of miles away from home, a micrometeoroid storm has left us with a severely damaged ship, two deceased crew, and the sneaking suspicion this trip was doomed from the start.

pegi.synopsis:
The content of this game is suitable for persons aged 12 years and over only.
It contains: Mild bad language

reviews.review:
Straight up love this game.  It's extremely unforgiving.  It's possible to make it to Mars with all crew alive, but if you think you're going to breeze through this, it's going to be a real short trip for the crew of the Iktomi.

Backstory is 'The Martian' meets 'The Twilight Zone'.  It's bad enough when you *start* the game with low food, a deranged crew, and a ship that's falling apart......but then things just get weirder and weirder the closer you get to Mars.  

Sound track is god damn amazing.

Learning curve deeper than it looks.  I suspect a lot of players, myself included, just started out by attempting to fix everything broken/damaged/on fire.  This will just end in tears.  After blowing up the Iktomi a few dozen times, you start to sort out the real strategy and hidden rules.  A couple posters complain about the lack of tutorial; legit beef, but the missions, outside of the 'regular' game, help *a lot* with the strategy and hidden rules.

I was sort of worried about role of dice in the game when figuring out if this was for me.  It seemed shallow, but Choice Provisions really gives you a lot of options with what to do with what you get.  Plan it dead on right, and you'll be mostly OK.  Throw it away and you'll be regretting it real soon.  

Starting out screwed from the word 'go' and still succeeding really makes you feel like a superhero.  Get your ass to Mars!

Great game; amazingly addictive even after I finally reached Mars (after a dozen failed attempts). Now I keep coming back to try new crew members and any new strategies those crew members might add. 

I do feel that I should say that I might not have persevered if the game had not had the Easy difficulty setting. I went into the game not expecting to win my first time- or even my first few times- but being able to make it to Round 6, then Round 9 over (and over and over) again let me know that, while I might be failing, I was figuring things out, and getting close. If I'd been soundly knocked out repeatedly very early on I'd have possibly been too discouraged to continue. Instead, when I finally beat the game on Easy, I was able to take a deep breath and, with a better feel for how the game works, move on to Normal. Mayhaps someday I'll transition to Hard? At which point I'll probably descend into space madness resort to the (in game) Cannibalism I've held off of so far...  will have to see!

This is a very decent (short) game. Nice neat presentation and gameplay concept. Ignore people moaning about the chance element, it's a dice game, it is what it is. However there are enough options and tactics available to outweigh the chance element and make for an absorbing and tense little game. Careful choices in astronaut deployment and dice allocation mean even a lousy throw of the dice can be turned to advantage. Lots of little touches like assists, astronaut specialities and research add choice and depth. It will certainly pass several evenings pleasurably for the price of a pint (if you get it on sale). You can take it at a leisurely pace and it's maybe one to play in between bouts with your ongoing favourite long games. Recommended, I'd be interested in more games with a similar concept. Background story is poor/cliched, but who cares?

[b][u]5 Things You Should Know about [i]Tharsis[/i][/u][/b]
[b]What's Is It?[/b]
Sci-Fi digital board game about a space ship headed to Mars (and managing to collide with just about every piece of space debris between here and there.)  This is a pure board game in a digital format.  There are actually dice that roll and get moved around - using a physics engine to roll 3D cubes, not typical computer RNG.  It's a resource management game with aspects of worker placement and Yahtzee-style set collections, for the board game geeks amongst us.  Overall, it's pretty tense.  They did a good job of balancing incoming threats so that you're always pushing the limit of your capabilities to keep things together.

[b]What's The Best Part?[/b]
I enjoyed the combination of resource management and worker placement.  You have to manage each crew member's health, stress level and dice, which represent their overall ability.  After rolling the dice, you need to place them in various "slots."  There's a generic "solve the current crisis" slot, which has a numeric target value you need to meet with pips rolled.  Then each module has an ability that can be used if you can put the right dice in place (some require a single die of value X+, others require a pair or a triple of any face value.)  You can slough off extra dice into research, which has you slowly building a "straight" of dice, 1 - 6, and these can then be "spent" to research things that grant benefits.

Sometimes rolling a particular value will cause injury, or make the die evaporate, until you solve the current crisis in your module, so you need to focus on crises first most of the time.

[b]What's The Worst Part?[/b]
I didn't find much to complain about in this one, honestly.  The astronauts' faces seem very low-poly compared to the rest of the graphics in the game, although that may just be a result of the portraits being "zoomed in" much closer than the rest of the ship, which we see from a further distance.  It felt incongruous, though.  I think it might've been better to use cel shaded or static 2D art for the portraits.  But this is clearly a nit-pick, the game is still fantastic as-is.

[b]Will I Like It?[/b]
If you're NOT into the modern board game hobby scene, you might be somewhat off-put by the board game format they've used.  This game could literally be printed physically and sold as such if they wanted to.  The only change needed would be relatively simple - converting the hazards into a deck of cards to be drawn from, or something like that.)

If you ARE into the modern board gaming scene, it depends on how you feel about the mechanics involved - resource management, worker placement and Yahtzee.  And co-op, I suppose (I mean, as a physical board game it would be 1 - X co-op - no traitor mechanics.)

[b]Why Should I Buy It?[/b]
Because you like the idea of digital board games, or you like board games enough to overlook the digital aspect.

This has been a 5TYSK review. (#0021)
100% luck based. there is no "winning" in this game

highlighted.name: I'm Going To Science The Snot Out Of This

igdb.name: Epistory
igdb.summary:
Epistory is an atmospheric adventure typing game that tells the story of a writer lacking inspiration who asks her muse to help write her latest book. 
 
In Epistory you play the muse, a fictional character in a world where everything is untold. Your adventure begins on a blank page, but the world will soon become larger and livelier as you gather inspiration, solve its mysteries and defeat its enemies. From movement to opening chests and fighting in epic battles, every element in the game is controlled exclusively with the keyboard. 
 
As you progress and explore the fantasy origami world, the story literally unfolds in the writer’s mind and the mysteries of the magic power of the words are revealed.

reviews.review: Enjoyable story, beautiful paper art style, immersive sound and music and most importantly I get to type away. LOL. This game give me all reason to buy mechanical keyboard and be statisfied typing endlessly while setting enemies on fire. The fox is so cool (and cute too). Besides, you can improve your typing skills in a FUN way! Even though I just can't seem to break the barrier of 30WPM speed. Long hours ahead!! XD

Epistory is a short and aesthetically pleasing typing game. The world is built from paper and the creators have used a variety  of methods to showcase their artistic style. 
Unfortunately I found the game's narrative a little - simple, and after a while it just became poetic drivel. Though each chapter (new area) brings a great new game mechanic and visual style, the enemy encounters become quite repetitive and a little uninspired compared to the world they're in. 
I'd recommend this for a short and visually pleasing experience and think the 3-4 hours length is pretty much spot on.
If you enjoy typing, this is most definitely a fun game.

Great game.  Inventive and enjoyable.  Great mechanics, I especially like the switching of powers using typed command during battles, added a certain tension as you had to switch power for enemies.  Storyline felt a bit contrived, but found myself getting into it as I went further.  Ending is possibly a slight letdown, but journey there is great.  Good atmosperic sound track also.

Ooookay, my high school typing teacher would be so disappointed in me. Actually, that's not true, since I learned on an electric typewriter, rather than a computer keyboard, so 45 wpm was pretty damn good back in the day (that day being 1986). And we guys thought we'd NEVER use typing skills in our lives, ever. Pfft.

What sucks is that this game forces me to go back to school, as it were, and relearn the proper way to type, rather than the insane way I normally do things. Having to do the basics all over again is helpful, though, and at least the game makes typing fun.

Well, when I say "fun", I mean the kind if you like juggling machetes and playing chicken with bullet trains. This game will stress out most folks, but it's still a blast if you keep at it. Plus, the story isn't half-bad. I have to mute the music, since it annoys me quickly, and the voiceover sounds like a friend of mine who used to stay up for 48 hours straight during finals week. Laconic much? Otherwise, I like it.

E2A--Anybody ever play an old typing game called Typing (or Typer, can't recall exactly) Shark? Same concept, different enemies, less forgiving. In harder levels, my name was Chum.

First and foremost, this game is absolutely beautiful. From the graphics, to how everything is treated as a story by having paper shift to create the environment, to having all words appear on the environment itself. It's really all lovely. The voice actress is really great, too. There's so much emotion and meaning behind her few words, for which I greatly appreciated.

One note, though: if you don't like typing games, you wont like this game. Plain and simple.

I enjoy typing games (ex: Typing of the Dead). This game stood out by having the concept of schools of magic. An enemy may need to be killed using fire, for example, or you may want to choose to use electric/spark magic because any hits against an enemy split off and hit a few other enemies nearby. I loved this mechanic different that made this game stand out against others.

An amazing game with a very beautiful story. 5 Stars on any day!
Story & Presentation: 5
Music: 5
Gameplay: 5

One annoying thing though, is when you reach a point that you have extra skill points and when you press tab it goes to the skill system instead of the default map.

It was an overall positive experience, though I felt as though the ending was kind of weak.  After so much cryptic storytelling throughout the whole game, I would have liked at least some sort of closure as to what happened in the game, as opposed to a brief 20 second clip.

Still, the art is beautiful and the gameplay engaging enough for a fun indie romp.  I recommend the game.
Beautiful artstyle, really well written and very unusual but fun gameplay. Teaches 10-finger-typing like a boss.

I am not that far in but the pacing, visuals and challenge have me hooked. Its a typing game, move the fox around and type the words to remove obstacles or defeat enemies. Its simple but fun and can be harder than you would think when you have 3 enemies coming at you and you have to type ANTIDISCRIMINATION after a volley of 3-4 letter words, it will throw you off. 

I got it on sale, worth every penny and even still at full price i think its worth it.

It is often said that it is harder to convey emotion through gameplay than words or visuals, but Epistory disprove that.

By using the typing as a core mechanic to progress within the game, and carefully choosing the words to type, as a player, we literally "play" the story threads, and can sometimes foreshadow the ending.

Progressing in the game "feels" like reading a book, almost with the tactile sensation of turning the pages. The art style is just perfect, and on top of that, overcoming the waves of enemies by typing fast and switching powers is really rewarding. It is almost as if you can feel the power of the words coming from your tip of your fingers.

Congratulations to the team!

A short but all so sweet game! I loved it to bits! The origami-like environment is beautiful, the music emotional accentuating and the story mysterious and only in fragments told as you progress in the game. At the beginning you have to get used to the mechanics because this game is designed to be played with the keyboard only, but after a while you'll don't even notice this anymore. Just one thing has to be said: If you are not familiar with 10-finger-writing this game will be really hard for you. In the later battles there is no time to look down on the keyboard and back to the display. But if you enjoy writing overall and like indie games then I highly recommend this game for you.

Overall: a fun, gentle videogame that was surprisingly entertaining in its simplicity. And I for one loved the animation style.

Details: This is a simple (not in a bad way!), but exquistely animated game. In some ways it reminds me of those "games" we played in school to teach us how to touch-type, but this is actually entertaining. There are puzzles and four different 'typing weapons'  you can use that have different effects on so-called 'monsters' (burn/freeze/shock/blow away the bug creatures). The game also has different modes--it will scale with how fast you can type if you want it to.
a nice puzzle & typing game. good to increase WPM for those who need.
The only good educational game I've ever played.

Original, vibrant, immersive.
Gaming at its finest.

Epistory Typing Chronicles is an isometric, story driven, dungeon crawler with a truly unique combat system by developer Fishing Cactus.

Epistory tells the story of a girl and her faithful fox steed as they attempt to repair a post-apocalyptic, tumultuous, world all through the power of typing. Players traverse a massive over-world which is unlocked one piece at a time, unfolding itself in front of the player as they progress through the story. The highlight of Epistory is the spectacularly designed map and dungeons which are far beyond what you would expect from a game of this caliber.

Additionally, the art direction of the game was an unexpected plus with its ability to tie in the art direction so beautifully and intimately with the story. The fact the origami style art in the game has a deeper meaning within the context of the story goes to show the care and heart this studio put into their game and should be noted by other developers, big and small.



The prime issue with Epistory is how tiresome the "combat" of the game becomes. For those who have played typing games before you know your brain an hands can only handle so much before you become fatigued and disinterested. This same issue occurs within Typing Chronicles as the more you play the more the typing based combat feels like a chore opposed to a feature. This becomes more and more apparent as the puzzles remain varied and interesting but are broken up by the more monotonous typing challenges. While introducing different "attack types" throughout the game does help ramp the difficulty and variability of the typing challenges it simply does not add enough excitement over the course of a 5-10 hour game.

There are additional issues with balancing of the game. While playing I only upgraded my stats 2-3 times as they never quite felt necessary to complete the missions particularly early on in the game. This would lead to me losing a typing challenge, using the stockpiled points, then having a massive power spike which allowed me to breeze through the challenge. This made the game feel less like I was developing my typing skill and instead using my artificial skill points to get past challenges.

It should be noted though, how the developers made a valiant attempt to keep the game pressing forward with their experience system. Many short (5-15 hour) games struggle to match player and story progression which leads to odd balance issues at the end of the game where the player is drastically overpowered or must grind experience to be strong enough to finish the game. Typing Chronicles does not fall into this trap and should be commended for it.

The story of Typing Chronicles, while occasionally thought provoking, quickly became a collection of disjointed audio files which were too vague and ethereal to drive player investment into the story. The bulk of the story is developed in the final chapter of the game and (without spoiling too much) essentially voids everything else we had seen and heard about the story previously. The last 20% of the game excellently developed the main character, provided context, and even tied the game play into the story. This though made the first 80% of the story feel like even more of half baked mess. 

Overall Epistory Typing Chronicles is a wonderful game for those looking to sharpen or test their typing skills, and should be used in every typing class moving forward. With excellent level and puzzle design the game delights with its Zelda-esque dungeon/over-world and origami based art style. The game though is held back by its repetitive combat system, odd balancing, and disjointed and overly ethereal story/tone.
it is a  6 hour astounding experience

This game is really different to anything else I've ever played or even seen in passing. Typing is made into a weapon as well as a method for discovery, it's a really great concept! The story is not overly obvious, you have to explore and find the story for yourself and it's great to see that what the narrator says in passing in this eery, calming voiceover has some substance in the life you are exploring.
Levelling up abilities is nice and easy with enough points gathered to make it possible but you do have to decide what you want and plan ahead, no spend thrifts allowed!
Overall, really enjoyable, challenging in a good way and loving the story!
P.S If you think you're a slow typer this will help you improve by miles!

If the idea interests you, then you WILL enjoy this game. 

There are 4 different styles of typing attack to acquire, and it WILL keep you on your toes, typing insane amounts of words really fast to kill off enemies. The game itself is very satisfying, picking up little clues about why you're there in this world reading the story that is LITERALLY unfolding in front of you, but you can also go back in afterward to complete any nests or pieces you may have missed. On top of that, there is an "Arena" area with four different levels, that is set up for you to go back in and challenge your typing skills through the bug distroying at ever increasing difficulty -as in the game, but this goes on for as long as you want to keep trying to score big. 

Again, PLAY THIS if you even think you'd like it. You wont be dissapointed.

*note, the game says to use EF and JI to move, which is advisable, but it will allow you to use the common WASD controlls as well

appDetails.name: Epistory - Typing Chronicles
appDetails.detailed_description:
Epistory is an atmospheric adventure typing game that tells the story of a writer lacking inspiration who asks her muse to help write her latest book.

In Epistory you play the muse, a fictional character in a world where everything is untold. Your adventure begins on a blank page, but the world will soon become larger and livelier as you gather inspiration, solve its mysteries and defeat its enemies. From movement to opening chests and fighting in epic battles, every element in the game is controlled exclusively with the keyboard.

As you progress and explore the fantasy origami world, the story literally unfolds in the writer’s mind and the mysteries of the magic power of the words are revealed.

Features


  • Explore a beautiful paper craft world: play as the muse riding a giant three tailed fox, lost in a fantasy 3D world
  • More than just typing: solve mysterious puzzles, unlock magic powers and defeat enemies in adrenaline pumping epic combats
  • A writer’s block? Collect fragments and inspirations points to unfold the story as you explore the origami world in the writer’s head. But there is more to the story than meets the eye…
  • All in keyboard: from movements, combats to even menus, control everything with a keyboard
  • Adaptive difficulty: if your hands fly around the keyboard or if you are a slow typist, the game features a dynamic difficulty system that evolves to fit each players’ skill set
  • Competitive Arena Mode: challenge other players for the top spot in the arena leaderboards
  • Play in your own language: game texts are localized in English, French, German, Spanish, Portuguese (Brazil), Russian, Polish with voice overs in English. The game supports several keyboard layouts (QWERTY, QWERTZ, AZERTY, BEPO, Dvorak, Workman and Colemak)

As you progress and explore this world, the story literally unfolds and the mysteries of the magic power of the words are revealed. It's an immersive, unique and exciting combination of both roleplaying and typing.

igdb.name: Mushroom 11
igdb.summary: An award-winning anti-platformer where destruction is the only way to move. Mold yourself into any form by destroying your cells, and traverse a devastated landscape filled with brain-twisting puzzles and bizarre mutations. Are you ready to break the mold?

reviews.review:
This is an incredible physics-based action puzzler. It's what I imagine you'd get if you crossed the Ecco the Dolphin game, with the World of Goo game with the Bladerunner movie, in terms of its combination of gameplay and atmosphere.

I was going to write a review earlier when I was at level 4, but I was reading some negative reviews saying it got too hard at later points, so I decided to finish all 7 levels to be thorough. I can honestly say the challenge level was not excessive at any point. Yes there were a handful of points that I was stuck on for a while, but isn't challenge part of the reason you play games? It is for me anyway. To be honest, I feel ripped off if nothing stumps me in a whole game. And I would say all of those moments were followed by an "Ohhh" revelation, usually me approaching the problem in a fundamentally wrong way, or not paying close enough attention to the mechanics of the movement.

It's a joy to "learn to walk" in this game. The resolution between figuring out the puzzle and making your organism carry your solution out is very satisfying -- SO many "Ohhh" moments! The visuals are flawless as is the soundtrack, the perfect ether to immerse you in the practical aspect of the mechanics and puzzles. I also feel like a 2nd play-through to 100% all the level collectibles/achievements would be just as fun (now I just need life to give me unlimited free time kthx... *cry*).

I don't get the time to play games often, but picking this game for the holidays was a great decision!

If you do play it, don't give up! Stay to experience the AMAZING CLIMAX :)

If you'd like a copy, I'll be giving away 5 free copies to the first 5 people who reply to this review!  Simply reply with "Mushrooms are delicious!" (or something expressing that you'd like to play the game), and I will friend you and gift it to you. (Please only people who didn't receive one of my previous giveaways.).

 Oh, check out DYE too, it rocks :)

I feel bad, but I am giving this game a mild "Not recommended" rating.  I feel bad because it is such an original concept and really is a good puzzle game... but it is so hard and very, very frustrating especially on the last 2-3 chapters.

In the game, you control an amobea / blob like creature.  You move by erasing part of yourself, which causes the remaining leftovers to grow in a somewhat random fashion.  Your creature can take on almost any shape, but getting how you want is not always so easy.  The goal of the game is to just reach the end of each chapter, of which there are 7.  Each level also ends with a boss, he being just another puzzle but where you need to somehow destroy him.  Things start out simple with you just needing to reach up to grab things and cross empty spaces.  By the end you will be pushing buttons, riding rockets, pushing balls and racing to make a bridge for them and many other complicated things.

This is all great but the levels are simply too long and many of the puzzles are too fiddly.  Since you grow in a somewhat random fashion, you can know what you want to do and still fail miserably at making your creature do it.  A few of the puzzles in particular will take the average player 10 to 20 attempts to complete them (you riding a rocket across a pool of acid for example).  If these difficult puzzles would have been reduced and the chapters been reduced in length, the game would have been fun and I would have recommended this.  Most players simply won't have the patience to get through to the end of the game, I almost gave up on it myself.  Those with lots of patience might want to try it out though if the concept looks intriguing, others should pass.

appDetails.name: Mushroom 11
appDetails.detailed_description:
Delete it and it will grow.
Mold an amorphous organism into any shape by pruning its cells. New cells will immediately grow, allowing you to traverse a mysterious world across brain-twisting obstacles, overcome swarms of bizarre mutated creatures, and understand the true nature of the devastation from which you emerged. The eerily beautiful visuals are complemented by the exquisite, ethereal soundtrack of British electronica legend The Future Sound of London, also available as DLC.

* Rock, Paper, Shotgun's Best Platformer of 2015
* IGN's List of Best Platformers and Most Innovative Games of 2015

igdb.name: Copoka
igdb.summary: Copoka is an mellow open world exploratory indie game about a bird trying to build his nest in a totalitarian city state.

reviews.review:
Copoka is a beautiful little game, the perfect example of the saying 'short and sweet'. The experience of being a bird, a silent observer to a country and it's citizens in strife is not for everyone. There is not a great deal of action and no danger. You fly around, collecting shiny things to adorn your nest. On your journey you listen in on conversations that make up a narrative of a country divided by hardship. You can either choose to stay and listen, or simply continue on your quest for shinies. 
There are a few collectibles and several achievements that extend the gametime somewhat. Flying around can take some getting used to with a keyboard, hence the strong reccomendation of a controller. After a rocky start though I got the hang of it soon enough.
The graphics are charming in their own way, simplistic, yet lovely. The music is very fitting, soothing, giving you time to really relax. 
While the game may have a short play time, and not a great variety of features, what is there is a zenful gem.

appDetails.name: Copoka
appDetails.detailed_description:
Copoka is an open-world exploratory indie game about a bird building its nest in a totalitarian city state. As a player, you are soaring free, high above the city of Copoka, as a contrast to the citizens below. Your goal is to find and collect twigs for your nest, and as you construct your home piece by piece a story of intrigue and politics beneath around you.

Key Features

  • Take wing and enjoy the freedom of flight
  • Experience a city boiling with strife and political turmoil
  • Eavesdrop on conversations to get the full story of the city

Story

The city of Copoka is in distress. Speakers all around the city proclaim the glory of the Great Leader and how she will bring salvation to a country in need, while people lament in the streets about starvation and dissatisfaction. Something is brewing in the back alleys of the slums. Whispers in the wind tell about a coming uprising, about an end to the suffering and new hope for the citizens of Copoka. Being a bird you can undertake the role of silent observer. By listening to people around the city a more nuanced picture of the brewing conflict is revealed - a conflict concerning clashing ideologies regardless of social standing or allegiance.

Of course, it’s up to you if you wish to stop and listen. After all, what are human concerns to a bird anyway?

igdb.name: Nuclear Throne
igdb.summary: Nuclear Throne is an action roguelike-like by Vlambeer about mutants fighting their way through a post-apocalyptic world. The radioactive waste in the world allows mutants to get ahead by mutating new limbs on the fly, the abundant availability of powerful weaponry make the quest to become ruler of the Wasteland one fraught with peril.
igdb.storyline: One of 12 nuclear anomalies/ mutant creatures embarks on a quest across various post- apocalyptic dimensions to claim the Nuclear Throne - a super weapon, details of whose purpose or creation unknown. Meanwhile, the Inter-Dimensional Police Department try their best not to let the mutant heroes discover the secrets of portal-based inter-dimensional travel and the Throne.

reviews.review: kind of like dark souls, but instead of linking the first flame, you sit on a radioactive chair.

This game is notorious for sure, but let's get into it anyway!

To put it simple, its a dope arcade spirited twin-stick shooter with rogue-lite elements. 
Procedural mechanics are very well balanced so that even if you don't care about lore you'll still benefit from it.
Post-game is wonderfull & give tremendous replayability, realization is top notch, gameplay fast & furious : this game is almost flawless. For real. 

Huge, huge hit. Any STG-enthousiast will enjoy this very much.

A game that rewards skill and time spent perfecting it. Various unlocks and the randomness of the roguelike elements add to the replay value. The mechanics and controls are tight and crisp. I always felt my deaths were a result of a mistake or failure to capitalize on an opportunity, and not something bullshit like finicky controls. The game can be frustratingly difficult but not due to poor design or a lack of polish. I'm the kind of person who will get frustrated with a difficult game after a while and put down it down and never go back to it, but I go back to Nuclear Throne because I know the only thing holding me back is myself.
GREAT GAme

Nuclear throne is a rougelike. That's already a special note to start on, because i'm a sucker for rougelikes. But this is no ordinary one, this is one of the most fun rougelikes i've come across so far, I just can't get enough of it. I've been going at it on and off for the last 3 days. With many characters to unlock, 2 endings, an infinite mode, and daily + weekly runs, it'll keep you around for a looong time
Pros: 
+Tons of unlockable stuff.
+All types of characters for all types of players
+A whole lot of guns.
+Basically a lot of content.
+Addictive.
Cons:
-Extremely low chance of future updates.
-Co-op isn't all that great, and you need a mod to play online.
ZE BEST GAME EVAR!!!!!!
yes

TLDR: Nuclear Throne is a top-down action game where you play as a mutant in a post-apocalyptic wasteland, where you will fight hundreds of enemies on screen at once. Nuclear Throne does everything it does seamlessly.

GAMEPLAY:
Skill based, tight, focused, and fast paced. You will be on the tips of your toes, dodging projectiles, and obliterating enemies at break neck pace the entire time. There is little to no down time except for when you get to pick your mutations (PERKS) after you level up by collecting rads (XP). Mutations range from necessary to useless, and you will quickly find out the proper pecking order. Weapons also have a similar range, from the Super Plasma Cannon (think BFG from Doom) to the Screwdriver, which might as well be called a toothpick [i]if[/i] it was useful. Finding the perfect combinations [spoiler](SPC + Ultra Shovel)[/spoiler] and using your characters abilities will be some of the best action based gameplay I've seen in 10 years straight of playing shooters. I would compare the speed and mechanics as closer to Quake and Doom than most of the modern FPS scene, which won't make sense until you pick up the game. I would go at great lengths to describe every little quirk of this game, but it would be a waste. Just play it.

MUSIC:
Atmospheric, and beautiful. Just listen to it, and you'll come to the same conclusion.

STORY:
Each character has a totally unique personality, and as the player you will be reminded of that pretty much the whole time in various unique ways. This ranges from Fish's guitar being a weapon, to Crystal polishing and grooming her body, to Plant munching on a dead bandit. The achievements all cater to their specific personalities too, which I won't spoil because it's way too much fun to find them all. The storyline also includes little quirks and details in the environments and text dialogue that it reads to you inbetween levels... All in all, this is suptle world-building at it's best and serves as a nice time waster when you're needing some down time. 

I easily give this game a well-deserved ten out of ten.
Just play Nuclear Throne. Buy it, and play it. There is no reason not to.

Also, you can play this game on a toaster, so that's a plus.
Neat
Yes.
My favorite of all Vlambeer games. Enough said.

This is my second account, after i loast the first, so i have alot of hours. Easily the most fun game ive played, and you can check my library. Its a classic rogue action game with tons of powerfull weapons, bosses, areas, and characters. There is a character for every playstyle.

This game is terrible, my brother bought it for me It was the worst choice of his life. The game only supports keyboard and mouse, I don't own a mouse so I cant shoot. I keep starting a match from my touchscreen but It doesn't support that either.

The strongest arguments against this game are the hardcoded 30fps framerate and enter the gungeon.  It has the problems inherent to a game locked at 30fps, with additional problems due to gameplay design choices.

Moving around is jittery in 30fps@240p.  Everything is.  The pixel art is kind of muddy.  There are a lot of cheap deaths.  Base movespeed is probably too slow for how fast enemy projectiles are, and you should probably be able to see further around you.

For comparison, let's talk about what enter the gungeon does that nuclear throne doesn't.   EtG goes on sale frequently for $7.50.  There are many more guns and they're a lot more distinct from each other.  There's a massive amount of items.  There are more bosses and enemies, which are mostly designed well.  The gameplay is more fair and intuitive.  There's a more compelling progression arc with more content to it.  Graphically, it's clean.  It supports widescreen and will run at 1440p and 144hz if you have the monitor for it.  Sound design is a lot better.

I'm okay with playing Nuclear Throne for some variety, but I generally wouldn't recommend it to other people.

appDetails.name: Nuclear Throne
appDetails.detailed_description: Nuclear Throne is a post-apocalyptic roguelike-like top-down shooter. Not 'the final hope of humanity' post-apocalyptic, but 'humanity is extinct and mutants and monsters now roam the world' post-apocalyptic. Fight your way through the wastelands with powerful weaponry, collecting radiation to mutate some new limbs and abilities. All these things and more you could do if only you were good at this game. Can you reach the Nuclear Throne?

igdb.name: Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas
igdb.summary:
A remasterd version of Oceanhorn from iOS. 
 
"You wake up and find a letter from your father. He is gone… The only lead is his old notebook and a mysterious necklace. What happened?

It contains: Non realistic looking violence towards fantasy characters - - Pictures or sounds likely to be scary to young children

reviews.review: Great game, like Zelda, nice gamepad support.

I can finally write a review for this game, now that I have unlocked all the achievements. The game is literally magnificent. I was one of the unlucky people who although was born in 90s, didn't have the chance to play a single Legend of Zelda game. This game looks and feels like one Zelda games but in with its own theme and world. I highly recommend this game to kids and adults as well. Really relaxing and good gameplay with joyful musics. I own it both on mobile and PC now but finished it on PC. I'm so happy to hear that there is a sequel coming up and hopefully a third one will also be made. 
However I have one tiny complaint. The fishing mechanics are really stale and not fun in my opinion. I had really hard time catching some of the fishes but finding them was even harder. Nonetheless, I went through the trouble and 100% this game. Don't miss this game out. Even the full price is worth for this game, you have my word.
reminds me of zelda games

One of the most overrated games with little to no redeemable, the dungeon is mostly pushing blocks, the combat is sluggish, the story is meh. The game weapons  is nothing new. If games are going to be inspired by something at least make something new like okami like zelda, but it has new ideas to distinguish itself to make a unique rather oceanhorn is inspired by zelda but does everything what the franchise is known for such as dungeon or bosses even worst. Oceanhorn lacks creativity in puzzle design compare to zelda, as Zelda is creative and very well designed.

Hope Oceanhorn 2 improves it's dungeon design

igdb.name: Avernum 2: Crystal Souls
igdb.summary: Huge indie fantasy role-playing adventure in a massive, underground land. Packed with over 100 towns and dungeons and an epic story. Fight to complete up to three distinct game-winning quests. Master over 60 spells and abilities. Hunt for hundreds of magical artifacts. Over 50 hours of gameplay.

reviews.review:
Perfect game,
Even on a sale or not just buy it if you like old school Rpg's;

Pos.
- Story rich
- Long game
- No bugs
- Cunning battles on hard and more
- Open world

Neg. 
- Not replayable 
- Fixed party (though you can start 4 guys and kill others and play one char and some npc's may join but this is not the ideal case)

Overall : 9,5 /10
I like tactics. This game has it. No wonder I player more than 100 hours of it.

appDetails.name: Avernum 2: Crystal Souls
appDetails.detailed_description:
Avernum 2: Crystal Souls is an epic, indie, fantasy role-playing adventure in a unique, massive world. The subterranean land of Avernum is full of strange caves, cunning dungeons, and the alien inhabitants of the underworld. Explore a massive, underground nation of tunnels and caverns, packed with over 100 towns and dungeons. Fight to complete up to three distinct game-winning quests.

Avernum 2: Crystal Souls features:


  • Epic fantasy adventure with over 50 hours of gameplay. An enormous underworld, with multiple nations and alien cultures.
  • Rich game system with over 60 spells and battle disciplines and a multitude of beneficial character traits to choose from.
  • Over 100 towns and dungeons.
  • Three separate game-winning quests. There are many ways to fight the invaders. Do just one of them or all three!
  • Unique races and settings make Avernum different from any adventure out there.
  • Dozens of side quests and hundreds of magical artifacts.

The story of Avernum 2 is self-contained, and previous experience with Avernum games isn't required.

igdb.name: Morphblade
igdb.summary: In Morphblade you move around a grid slicing, smashing and bursting waves of nasty red bugs. Each tile you move to transforms you into a different weapon: on a Blades hex you can slice enemies on either side of you, on an Arrow you can launch yourself through two enemies in a row.

reviews.review: [b][i]Morphblade[/i] is outstanding.[/b] Reminds me of an actiony version of [i]Hexcells[/i]. Everything about this is fantastic - every piece of it is intentional and well thought out. I would have paid $15 easily for this. Just dig in and figure it out for yourself, there are absolutely no 'cons' for this title.

Well this game came as a surprise.  I love strategy games, and upon reading about this, and also seeing that it was inspired by Imbroglio, I knew I had to give it a try.  Glad I did, as strategy games like this are few and far between.

As you can gather from the game's description, the core mechanic of the game is that when you move onto a hex, your shape is changed into the shape shown on that hex.  And with these different shapes, comes different abilities.  So your attacks and powers are dependant on the hex you are standing on at the time... your actual "ship" has zero inherant powers of it's own.  None.  You are completely dependant on the grid itself to fight back against the unending bugs.

The true depth though, is where it then goes with that mechanic.  Each hex can gain experience.  For the three offensive hexes, they gain experience each time you make a kill when you started the turn on their position.  For the three special hexes, they gain experience whenever an enemy bug dies on top of them.  Hexes get one experience point at a time, and each time a hex gains 6, it can gain new abilities, however the abilities that you can add to that hex are entirely determined by which hex types are next to it.  For example, if a smasher hex (lets you attack an adjacent enemy without moving) is levelled up, and there is a healing hex next to it, one of the options available will be to give it the ability to heal you whenever you destroy an enemy with it.  However, these upgrades arent universal:  Upgrading a smasher hex only upgrades that one specific smasher... the others on the board are unaffected.  So each smasher hex could end up with different powers depending on what is next to it when it levels up.   This means that the board's structure is EVERYTHING.  All of the strategy is determined by it.  What's more, the strategy is deepened by the position of each individual hex in relation to other hexes, as the different powers each can gain really do make a huge difference.  And lastly, after each enemy "wave", a variety of possible new hexes appear on the edges of the board, and you can go and choose one, expanding the board further.  The bigger it gets, the more possibilities there are, but the complications multiply as the board keeps growing.

That of course isnt enough though:  the other half of the game is the different enemies.  At the start of each wave, enemies spawn in a group onto the board.  They take two turns to spawn:  for the first turn you'll see tiny versions of them on the space they are about to appear on (and they are invincible during this) and on the next, they fully spawn.  After that, they can act.  This means that you have a bit of time to look at the positioning of new monsters and can use that free turn to react to the situation.  This is good, because these enemies get pretty nasty.  Basic bugs are simple, just coming directly at you and dying in one hit, but things get really wonky when other abilities are added to them, such as armor, the ability to snipe, or explosiveness, which outright destroys the hex it's on when the enemy dies (losing a strong, upgraded hex to an explosive foe really sucks).  The good thing is, there are ways to counter everything in the game.  THose explosive jerks for instance.  Normally, they'll ALWAYS explode when killed.  But if you have an acid hex next to another acid hex, and level one of those up, selecting the acid-based power available to it, that acid hex will not only strip enemies that land on it of their armor (which is the acid hex's default ability), but it gains the additional ability to defuse explosive enemies.  There isnt really any all-powerful combination though; the enemy selection is designed as such that they can counter you as well.  Paying attention to enemy positions in relation to absolutely every other freaking thing is important.

The best thing though is that the game is very well balanced.  Of the 6 hexes, there arent any that are going to be rarely-used, all 6 are equally important.  The same goes for all the different abilities that can be gained by each type.  And there really isnt any single strategy that will always work.  One way or another, you absolutely will have to think your way through things anew every single time, and the situation just keeps changing througout each run.

The interface is nice too.  Everything is easy to read, easy to spot, easy to use... it's all very intuitive, clean, and efficient.  And you can right click on anything for more info.

The one disadvantage the game has:  There is NO other content than this basic mode.  None.  There's no unlockables, no "campaign", no other modes.... this even lacks a title screen, which I find moderately baffling.  This is effectively a game in it's absolute most purified form, and for some players, that could be an issue.  The game really is ENTIRELY about the core experience.  It reminds me of alot of older arcade games in that way:  those also had no seperate modes, no unlockables... it was just the absolute pure single experience and not a single thing else, with the goal being to score as high as you can (which is the goal here too).  So, this is something you need to keep in mind when deciding wether to buy this or not.

For me though, that's not even remotely an issue.  I play alot of games that have that aspect.  And one way or another, this is just a blast to play.  And with each run being not all that long yet still very deep, it has that "one more go" aspect to it, and I expect this one will keep me coming back over and over again.   It's fun, it's deep, it's challenging, it's the sort of strategy game I really like.

I do wish/hope that this can get released on mobile, too.  I'd absolutely love to have this on my iPad.  It would work just as well there as it does here.   But for now, this absolutely will do.   Highly recommended.
small price - small game - big fun
Excellent, mechanically dense game. Well worth the tiny asking price.

I've found this game incredibly addicting. This is a puzzle game, but it feels much more... tactical. Maybe it's because most puzzle games aren't out to kill your character. On the surface, it's simple as heck. But it gets complicated as time goes on. One mistake leads to your ultimate downfall after a certain point. 

There's so many ways this game could go, as goes for all randomized games. If you don't like sitting there repeatedly doing the same thing over and over, this probably isn't for you. If you like variance, then this would probably bore about as fast as rolling a ball back and forth. (But that's still amusing to me as well!) 

Like breaking your own records? Testing your tactical mind? Reptitive gameplay, simple yet so deep?
Okay, I think I'm going over-the-top with this...
I hope this review helps you check out this little 5$ Indie. It's a cool little game that I'm real glad I bought.

Feels a bit like a browser game but the simple interface and controls hide a deep, tactical experience. Fulfils the following cleches:

[*]"Just one more game"
[*]Learn something new every game
[*]Something to fill an idle 10 minutes
[*]Every defeat is your own fault

A major aspect is choosing a new tile at the end of each round. You quickly move from "What I could use now" to "What I'll need in the future" to "What and where I'll need to survivewhen things get [i]really[/i] rough". It's extremely satisfying to be saved by a strategy you put in place a dozen rounds ago.

Aside from improving the AI, and maybe adding difficulties (and acheivements!) additional complexity would only spoil the elegant simplicity.

It's not world changing or expansive but what it does, it does very well.

Fantastic game with simple mechanics but a lot of strategic thinking. Similar to Chess, Checkers, and other similar strategy games, the mechanics are incredibly barebones yet the game still ends up putting you in complex situations where you'll die if you mess up. It's also incredibly addicting; I'd definitely recommend this for $5.

This developer to me makes great games and this one is no exeption. This is a simple puzzle game, and its very additing. Hopefully there will be good updates in  the future.

(would be better if it was $2 cheaper)

Decent puzzle game that has you thinking a couple of moves ahead as you plan out where best to move across the board. Set up combos of various tile types, that play off each other. It's a simple game to learn, but difficult to get really good at as a bit of luck is required for a really good run at it. It's certainly worth your time. (best so far: level 47).

This is a [b]GREAT[/b] game... to pass the time. The concept is interesting, and it is implemented in a fun and easy to understand way. Gameplay feels very diverse, yet it still maintains balance. All in all it feels very well thought out. 

That being said there are still a few areas I think this game lacks in. The main thing being replayability. There is only one game mode. In this game mode, you start off with a map/grid of sorts, and you complete waves. After completing a wave you unlock "tiles" from the map. There are different types of tiles, each of which do different things and interact with other tiles in different ways. When unlocked you have somewhat of a choice of which tiles go where. 

Having such a range of different tiles that interact and do different things, and having the ability to choose which tile goes where is what gives this game such a diverse feeling. But after a certain wave, all the tiles are chosen, and that diversity slowly becomes a mundane and methodical "survival" game (albeit there are enemies that can destroy tiles which adds another level of depth to the game). 

But there could be other game modes that add a level of replayability. A timed mode where you have a certain amount of time to get to the furthest wave possible. Or you have to reach a certain wave as fast as you can. And your scores are put up against other players. Or a gamemode where the tiles and enemies for each wave is predetermined and you have to find a way to survive, bringning out more of a puzzle-esque feel. Or some form of multiplayer gamemode. Even achievements or playercards would give it some sort of replayability.

But as it stands now, there is nothing about this games that shouts for me to come back and play it again, unless I have nothing else to do and am just biding my time with something else. Don't get me wrong, I do feel as though I got my money's worth so I will recommend it, but that doesn't mean this game couldn't be better.


tl;dr
[u]Pros[/u]
[list]
  [*]Fun
  [*]Diverse Gameplay
  [*]Easy to learn Game Mechanics
[/list]

[u]Cons[/u]
[list]
  [*]Limited to one game mode
  [*]Little to no replayability
[/list]
Simple, fun, and unique game mechanics. Well worth five dollars.

At the time of writing I have a mere 5 minutes in Morphblade. This is because it just released on Steam. However, I have put many, many hours into the various pre-release builds, and keenly followed it through development.

To keep it brief, this game is a small, side-project made by Tom Francis, who brought you Gunpoint, is bringing you Heat Signature, and Floating Point is in the mix too. Plus other smaller projects. This is certainly a smaller project, a tiny game similar to the likes of Terry Cavanaugh, who made VVVVV and Super Hexagon. It follows the same principle, a concept, with a layer or two of depth and complexity.

You could pick this up and play it for a few minutes, or play it for five hours, either is great fun. Is it worth it for the price? Just. As a polished toy, this is just about worth the couple of quid/bucks/unit of currency that it costs.

[b]In conclusion, I'd say this is simple, keeps you going with random elements, with many, many hours of fun to be had. Good job, Tom![/b]
Fun, simple puzzle game that has a surprising ammount of depth hidden away
Simple to learn, hard to master
Turn based survival puzzle where you have to fight against onslaught of ever increasing number of "enemies" while maintaining you board and thinking several steps ahead of you.
Wow!  Very cool puzzler somewhat in the vein of Hoplite or Imbroglio (great tactical mobile roguelite/puzzlers).

Morphblade is one of those games that straddles the line between "casual" and "strategy": you can play through a quick game when you have five minutes of free time and you're not feeling particularly thoughtful; or you can set aside a few hours and try to best your high score as you try to set up the perfect combination of tiles to keep one step ahead of your enemies. It plays like some sort of calvinball-chess, each tile having its uses and drawbacks, and you need to use all of them as the insectoid enemies swarm the board and overwhelm you. I enjoy the strategic aspect as much as I enjoy its throwaway nature - if I'm not feeling particularly motivated I'll throw this on for a few minutes and play around, but when I really focus on it I'm pushing to try and get the highest score I can, working out the best combination of tiles and upgrades to keep the swarm at bay. Each new game is a learning experience.

Relaxing game that really makes you think. Deceptively simple on the surface, Morphblade is easy to learn and hard to master. You can jump right in and have a good time, while still having fun later by trying different strategies. There are many ways to play, and each is satisfying in its own way. ~Highly Recommended~
Great game, amazing fun and can't see anything wrong with it! I realised this would be a great phone game! I would gladly pay again to have this on my phone!

This game is great. It is simple, easy to learn but hard to master. I like to play it for a few minutes each day, to relax. It is really great fun. Though i might imagine it would also work great on mobile, where i could play it on the bus etc. I would really love to see it there, though pc is also fine. 

Great dev with great games :)

also: thanks Nerd³ :D

appDetails.name: Morphblade
appDetails.detailed_description:
In Morphblade you move around a grid slicing, smashing and bursting waves of nasty red bugs. Each tile you move to transforms you into a different weapon: on a Blades hex you can slice enemies on either side of you, on an Arrow you can launch yourself through two enemies in a row. Between waves, you choose how to build out the grid, and upgrade your most used hexes with new abilities.

  • Hammer: lets you stay put and smash a single enemy in front of you
  • Blades: kill enemies on either side as you move
  • Arrow: plunge right through an enemy and come out the other side
  • Repair: repairs any damage you've taken when you move here
  • Teleport: move to anywhere else on the grid
  • Acid: strips tough enemies of their armour, leaving them vulnerable

Killing bugs earns you upgrades for your hexes, and each hex type can be cross-bred with every other type to take on some of its properties. Upgrade an Arrow with Acid and it can kill armoured enemies. Upgrade a Hammer with Blades and you can kill three enemies at once without moving. Upgrade a Teleporter with a Repair and you'll be healed each time you teleport.

Upgrades can even be stacked, so you can end up with an Arrow that propels you with infinite range, kills everything in your path, penetrates armour, knocks back everyone near your destination, heals you, and doubles as a teleporter.

The idea for tiles determining your weapon came from the iOS game Imbroglio by Michael Brough, which is great, and Morphblade is developed and released with his permission.
